Sir,

I beg to advise you that I have received a letter from Captain Walter Houghton, of the Salvation Army Mission at Glen Vowell, in which he requests me to place before you for consideration his application for a grant to the Salvation Army of Rental for the Building now used by the Department as a school.

During the last few weeks the Salvation Army authorities have done considerable repairs to the Glen Vowell Indian Day School, the inside has been lined with durable material and as soon as weather permits will be painted. I am given to understand that some $250.00 will have been expended on the school.

The repairs have made a great improvement both in appearance and comfort as previous to these the school was very cold in severe weather, in spite of a good fire. The example shown by the Army has induced some of the Indians of the village to make improvements to their homes.

In view of the above I do not hesitate to recommend that a small rental of $8.00 per month be paid for the use of the building now used as the Glen Vowell Indian Day School.

Your obedient Servant,

Indian Agent

The Secretary,
Department of Indian Affairs,
OTTAWA, ONT.
Ottawa, March 7th, 1924.

Sir:

I have to acknowledge receipt of your letter of the 26th ultimo, regarding the request of the authorities of the Salvation Army for rental for the building now used for school purposes at Glen Vowell.

In reply I beg to say that the Department does not wish to pay rental for a church owned building in a case where the school is conducted jointly by the church and the Department. It is noted that the Salvation Army has recently expended the sum of $250 in repairs to the building. We would prefer to assist by way of a grant towards the repairs, rather than pay rental for the building. If you can obtain from the authorities of the Salvation Army receipted accounts, in duplicate, covering an expenditure up to $150, the Department would be prepared to provide a grant to that amount towards the cost of the repairs. You should attach the receipted accounts to proper voucher forms, certify the same, and send to the Department. It is hoped that this arrangement will be satisfactory to the authorities of the Salvation Army, and that the grant towards the cost of the repairs will be acceptable in lieu of the rent.

Kindly give this matter your early attention, and, if the authorities agree, you should forward receipted accounts, properly certified, as requested.

Your obedient servant,

J. D. McLean,
Asst. Deputy and Secretary.

Sir,

I beg to advise you that I have just heard from Captain W. Houghton, of the Glen Vowell Mission. I am informed that the Salvation Army headquarters at Winnipeg appreciate the offer of the Department to pay the sum of $150.00 towards the cost of repairs and painting the building used for school purposes at Glen Vowell.

Some considerable time elapsed before I could get anything definite as they could not understand why the Department did not want to pay rental for the building; however, in the end I satisfied them.

On completion of the painting I will have Captain Houghton submit figures of the cost with the receipted accounts, covering an expenditure up to $150.00.

Your obedient servant,

Indian Agent

The Secretary,
Department of Indian Affairs,
OTTAWA, ONT.

Dear Sir:

I beg to inform you that Capt. W. Heughton of the Salvation Army Mission at Glen Vowell has approached me in connection with some very necessary work to be done at the Glen Vowell Indian Day School, and he asks if the Department will kindly assist the Mission in the cost of the work:- say Half-cost as on a previous occasion. From the standpoint of Safety and Sanitation, this Work would be a great improvement, in my opinion. The following is what I estimate the cost of the work:-

BRICK CHIMNEY.

The old pipes besides being dangerous, are constantly dropping Creosote on the floor and Desks, and from every point of view a Brick Chimney is most desirable.

I estimate the cost at.....$50.00

NEW FLOORING.

The old floor is now almost too bad to keep clean.

Cost of 1200 ft. No. L Hemlock including assistance in laying and incidentals.... $100.00

KALSIMINING.

The interior walls and Ceiling are now getting very dingy and the cost of this work would not exceed the sum of........ $40.00

Total Cost $190.00

I would recommend that the Department give this matter kind consideration.

Your obedient servant,

Indian Agent.

The Secretary,
Department of Indian Affairs,

Ottawa, February 13, 1930.

Sir:

Referring to that portion of your report on the Glen Vowell Indian Day School for the month of January last, and also to the requisition which was forwarded by the teacher for classroom supplies, it is noted that a suitable school bell is required. In this connection I have to say that our funds for the balance of the present school year are entirely assigned, and it would not be possible to give consideration to the supplying of a bell until our appropriation for the next fiscal year is available. In the meantime, however, and before the Department could place the order, I have to request that you will furnish full information as to the type of bell required. I enclose herewith a page from a catalogue showing the type of bell we supply to be installed in a tower or cupola or on a suitable covered stand erected on the school grounds. You should state where the bell would be hung, and also the size required as per the enclosed. Full shipping directions should also be given. When we have the above information, and funds are available, consideration will then be given as to whether a bell can be supplied or not.

Dear Sir:

Re-Roof on Glen Vowell School.

I beg to inform you that the shingles on the Glen Vowell School need to be replaced as soon as possible, as the roof is leaking and the beaver board on the ceiling is being stained.

This school has not been re-shingled before so you will readily understand that the present shingles are in very poor condition. Possibly owing to the extreme weather conditions of last fall and winter has hastened their decay. At any rate there are several large cracks near the top. It started to leak two years ago and patched it up then but it is beyond repair now and needs re-shingling.

Could this job be done during the Easter holidays so that it will not interfere with the school work and a carpenter will be home from trapping at that time?

Kindly give this matter due consideration,

Dear Sir:

Last night, when I examined the foundation posts under the Glen Vowell Day School, I found them so decayed that I believe new foundation posts should be put in at once. The foundation posts of the porch and the surface of the porch should be repaired at the same time.

In all, it would take approximately 100 lineal feet of cedar piling for foundation posts at $8 per foot would cost $80.00. The labour to take out the old posts and to put in new posts would cost about $20.00. The lumber and nails for the porch would cost about $4.50 and the labour $2.00. The material and labour for the foundation and the porch would not exceed $34.50.

Will you please recommend that this work be done before any damage is done as the result of the faulty foundation.

Yours very truly,

A.F. Parkinson
Major.

D. M. MacKay, Esq., Indian Commissioner for B. C., Vancouver, B. C.

October 11, 1945.

In reply to your letter of October 5th, I wish to advise that Miss Brierly, Teacher of the Glen Vowell Indian Day School, informs me that about four children from the far end of the village bring their lunches to school and that there are approximately seven or eight other children of more or less destitute families, who could very well benefit from a hot meal or hot drink. Under these circumstances I would recommend that Miss Brierly's request for the $7.00 per month for mid-day meals be approved. This village is spread out along the river bank and is somewhat different from some of the other reserves with the houses built in comparatively close proximity to the school.

This teacher, at some future time, would like to commence a domestic science course, having the Department provide the materials for cooking, which would be used for the benefit of the above mentioned pupils. This would then have the dual purpose of the scholars being taught the art of cooking by one having graduated in Home Economics, and serving such cooking for mid-day meals. I would appreciate your comments in this regard, which I consider a very worthwhile course to be taught in all schools, where possible.

S. Mallinson,
Indian Agent.
Indian Affairs Branch, Dept. of Mines & Resources, Ottawa.

Indian Affairs. (RG 10, Volume 6391, File 811-5, part 2)
Indian Affairs Branch, Dept. of Mines and Resources, Ottawa.

During Inspector Coleman's visit to the Babine Agency, Miss E. Brierly, teacher of the Glen Vowell Indian Day School advised him that she had replaced the fence around the school grounds at her own expense and asked if the Department would reimburse her for the expenditure. She was advised to take the matter up with the Indian Agent but apparently was not able to do so prior to his leaving the vicinity on holiday leave and consequently forwarded her accounts totalling $72.60 for fence posts, lumber and labour to this office. I intend to refer the matter to Mr. Indian Agent Mallinson in order that further details with respect to materials and labour returns may be secured but in the meantime it would be appreciated if you would advise if funds are available for reimbursing Miss Brierly.

I may say that the school building and teacher's residence at Glen Vowell are, as far as is known, the property of the Salvation Army, and as we have had the use of them without rent for many years, despite the fact that other church buildings in this Agency are rented by the Department, it is felt the Department should pay the cost of the fencing in question and other future maintenance of the buildings until such time as we are in a position to construct buildings of our own.

For D. M. MacKay,
Indian Commissioner for B.C.
Ottawa, July 6, 1946.

Major D. M. MacKay, Indian Commissioner for B.C.,
P.O. Box 70, Vancouver, British Columbia.

I have your letter - No. 1-11-3 - of the 22nd ultimo, with reference to the fence around the grounds at the Glen Vowell Indian Day School.

Prince Rupert, Jan. 3 1910

The Secretary,
Department of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa.

Sir,

Gwinoha or Kitwinshilqu is the village at the foot of the Big Canyon about eight miles below Aiyansh on the opposite side of the swift river. There are two little villages, the old and the new, not far apart with a good trail between. Rev. J.B. McCullagh has the oversight of this place and for two or three years has had school amongst them. Alfred McKay the native school teacher is the same man who taught the Lakkalzap school for several years. He has built a house in the new part of the village, taught school there all last winter and is teaching there now. Under Mr McCullagh's oversight he has done good work not only among the children but in night school among the men. We think that this work deserves a grant of $300 a year. I understand from Mr McCullagh that he forwarded the school returns but mail service is irregular and letters so often go astray that it is possible they were not received. Another possibility is that Mr Lorenz, knowing no grant was made for this school, did not consider he should send them on. I remember some remark to this effect.

Yours faithfully,

Sgd. F.H. DuVernet.
Bishop of Caledonia.
Ottawa February, 5th 1911.

Right Reverend Sir,

In reference to the grant for the school which is being conducted by Alfred McKay at Kitwillucshilt further information is desired. If there are sufficient children and if their parents are so located that they can attend the school regularly the question of allowing a grant will receive consideration.

Your Lordship's obedient servant,

R.C.Inspectorate,
1876 Fender St., Vancouver, B.C.,
May 22, 1911.

J.B. McLean Esq.,
Secretary, Department of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa.

Sir,

I have the honor to report that when visiting the Naas River in the month of April, the Indians of "Gwinaha" (the middle village on the Naas) came to me to ask help for a school for their village in which there are eighteen children of school age. The people are very anxious for their children to be taught. I also met Mr. W. Myers (brother of Judge Myers of Winnipeg) who has lived in their village for twelve months.

Mr. Myers had gone with the Post Simpson Indians to the Naas to see the eelichan fisheries in March, 1910. There he met the "Gwinaha" Indians, and after hearing they had neither teacher nor missionary, accompanied them back to their village when the fishing was over. There he has lived in an Indian house, the Indians having boarded off a corner of the old building for his use.

He has taught an adult Bible class five days a week, and has also taught the Indians how to make bricks, which they are using for fireplaces; has cared for the sick, besides making many reforms in the village.

In the first week of March, 1911, the Chief said to Mr. Myers, "you have been with us one year now, the winter has been very cold, the house you live in poor, and are food is not good. Are you not tired and are you going to leave us when we go away to fish the eelichans, or will you come back? We shall be sorry for you to go as people have learned so much." Mr. Myers replied that it was his intention to accompany them to the fishing and then to return and stay with them.

A few days after this the women of the village waited on him in a body, thanking him for what he had done for the village, and expressing how glad they were that he intended to stay. They then presented him with a feather bed, blankets, and stand, mats, and a
Mr. Myers is anxious to have a day school, but does not have any school supplies, as he has been using Bibles and Hymn books only. He is about fifty years of age, and was formerly a newspaper man, and a genius at all kinds of work. The only financial help he has received, is such that his brother, the Judge, has sent from Winnipeg. I might add that the disinterested way in which this man has lived and worked has made a profound impression upon both whites and Indians, on the river. (Mr. Myers told me he intends to make bricks for a house, as they have good clay near the village and also to teach the people farming.)

I would recommend that a school be authorized at this village, that school supplies be furnished and that a grant of one hundred dollars a quarter be granted. He is a most useful man on the reserve, and I cannot speak too highly of the self-sacrificing work he is doing.

His mission is not connected with any denomination, but has the esteem of all. His Lordship Bishop De Vernet highly esteem the man and the work he is doing, and spoke to me to see if help could not be given.

Dear Sir,---In reply to your letter (no.386549 of June 16th.) I beg leave to thank you for the assistance promised to our educational efforts among the Indian people at Gwinoha, from September 1910 to March 1911. ARCHIVES PUBLIQUES

CANADA
Gwinotha is an Indian settlement situated at the foot of the canon on the Naas River, about 40 miles from the mouth, in Northern B. C. It is located on a very fertile and level piece of land in shape similar to a right-angled triangle, the sides forming the right angle being about two miles long. The soil is a river silt and vegetable mould of a depth of about two feet, underneath which are sand and gravel. It is bounded by a lava bed, the Naas river and a warm water creek, issuing from underneath the lava and flowing along the base of a range of high mountains. Across the Naas there nestles among the mountain peaks a huge glacier.

The people were all heathen until about five years ago, when, under the earnest ministry of Rev. J. B. McCullagh, of Aiyansh, they renounced heathenism and embraced Christianity. A short time after they started to build a church and two years ago they became anxious to have a White missionary stationed in their own settlement. I was on the river making a study of the Indian people at the time and at the earnest solicitation of the Gwinotha people and with the hearty consent of Rev. J. B. McCullagh I accepted the position, assuredly gathering by many unmistakable signs that the hand of God was in the movement, and have been promoting the work to the best of my ability since that time. The work was entered upon and continues to be developed on the lines of faith. The position carries no salary except a small grant from the Indian Department of the Dominion Government in support of the day school, the said grant beginning last April, after the educational work which had been carried on without it for a year had been favorably reported to the governmental headquarters by the Inspector of Indian educational institutions. Many kind friends have been raised up to sustain me in the work, being constrained by the love of Christ so to do, and I am very much interested and encouraged in the work and fascinated with the tremendous scope for development.

The work is being prosecuted in four departments, namely: in the spiritual, sanitary, educational and industrial, on all of which good progress has been made. The Indian people have put in a good deal of co-operative work on their church building and bought all the materials with their own money, and have so far completed a nice frame structure 26x40 feet that we have been able to hold services regularly within it since January 22nd, 1911. No help, financial or otherwise, was asked for or received by this heroic native congregation until the time came for them to furnish the church, and this they could not do themselves and last spring they asked their fellow Christians in the Church abroad to come to their assistance. The response was disappointing to them, yet a few sympathetic friends who admired their zeal and honored their faith were raised up to their assistance. During 1911 the sum of $130 was received to help furnish the church, but this has not been enough to seat it. They need an organ, a baptismal font, a holy table, a lectern and a pulpit and furnishings for...
the same. There has also been received during the past year $5 for our Woman's Auxiliary and $145 in cash, a due bill for $30 worth of lumber and the donation of the lumber of an old building which will furnish enough material to build a mission house large enough for all present requirements, but doors, windows, flooring, ceiling, shingles, finishing, hardware, paints, etc., must be supplied from other sources. A small house, 16x26 feet, partially completed, was purchased for $100, and with a few dollars more expenditure on it this has been made fairly fit for occupancy, but it is much too small for our work and entirely unfurnished. However, with a few articles lent by the Indian people we have set up bachelor quarters therein. But when this small place has to be used as a bedroom, kitchen, pantry, store room, school, etc., it can readily be seen under what disadvantages the work of the mission is being prosecuted. The W.A. has been very active in raising money by the sale of their handywork and they have already spent $70 in furnishing the church and now have about $35 more in their treasury. There is a good church organization and an enthusiastic Church Army.

An assortment of medical and sanitary supplies, and a book on hygiene and home nursing has been received. Our efforts in this department are directed towards preventing serious illness and teaching a more sanitary mode of living.

The Indian Department has supplied the books and school requisites and furniture for the day school which we have established and the children are making good progress. Kind friends have also supplied us from time to time with magazines and periodicals illustrating stories and current events, which have been found very interesting to both old and young and an important educational factor. Besides the day school for the children night school is held, which is well attended by the older folks and a broader view of life is being presented to them.

An effort is being made to create an agricultural and industrial activity among these people, and if satisfactory progress is to be made in this department of the work, it must be demonstrated to the Indians by actual results that they will be able to make enough ready cash out of their farming operations to buy their groceries, flour, sugar, tea, coffee, oatmeal, rice, beans, and other necessaries for the table; their furniture and lumber and clothing and whatever else they require actual money for, which in this valley must amount to at least $500 a family per annum. This, of course, cannot be done with a spade and a garden rake on an indifferently cultivated plot of ground 100 feet square, but with potatoes selling at from two to five cents a pound and all other farm products in proportion and unlimited market; now growing up at Prince Rupert, Stewart, Goose Bay and other places within a day's run by river boat direct from the farm, this would be a very easy task even without intensive farming on a scientific basis. Acres of ground must be cleared of its scrub and spare timber and the work done with modern labor-saving implements and power machinery. It has already been demonstrated that all kinds of garden stuff grow in profusion and of excellent quality and that small fruits yield abundantly. The soil is good and the climate is almost ideal for vegetable growth. Now we propose to demonstrate to the Indian the profitableness and desirability of farming on the lines indicated, but we cannot accomplish much without help.

To prosecute successfully the four-fold work of this mission requires personal and intelligent attention and also a
good deal of money. As missionary in the field it gives me great delight to actively promote the work, and if the money or its equivalent is furnished by "The missionaries at home" regular dividends will be paid from the never-failing Treasury rich in blessings—not in proportion to the amount given, but by the love that prompts and the sacrifice involved.

Those who read the Pioneer and desire further information will be cheerfully furnished with full particulars and all enquiries will be received with pleasure and courteously answered.

THE TEMPLARY OF FAITH.

Our prayer circle is called "The Templary of Faith." Our motto is, "Have faith in God;" our declaration of faith is, "United in faith, we await the coming again of the Lord Jesus Christ;" our scripture warrant is, Luke 18, 1-8. Our hope is that The Templary of Faith will become an enduring testimony to the Faith of the Son of God, for the encouragement of future generations and the strengthening of the Church of the present day. The Templary is opened daily for prayer and thanksgiving for answered prayer; the petitions of the members from whom special requests have been received are then brought to the foot of the throne of our great High Priest for His merciful consideration. All who are able to subscribe to the declaration of faith are entitled to become Templars. It is our desire that all applications for membership shall be accompanied by a short favorite text of scripture to be inscribed upon the records of the Templary. Let us unite and make The Templary of Faith a powerful influence as a Faithful Testimony.

CHRISTMAS TREE ENTERTAINMENT.

The fall term of the Gwinotha day school was closed on Friday, Dec. 22, with a Christmas tree entertainment, and oh, my! if all those who contributed articles with which to decorate the tree could have been present to see the delight the event gave to all the people in the village they would have been repaid ten-fold. Santa Claus has become the jolly St. Nicholas of these Indian children as he does of all children wherever he goes. Willing hands helped to decorate the school room with three large mottoes—"A Merry Christmas," "Happy New Year," and "Glory to God in the Highest." They also made paper flowers and ribbons displaying the national colors and other ornaments, which made the school room look like fairy land. The boys went out and got a fine large spruce tree, almost a perfect cone. We notified those whom we knew would be delighted to help to make the hearts of these Indian children glad during the happiest season in all the year early in October that we were expecting Santa Claus to entertain the school. There was a hearty response, but alas Jack Frost seriously interfered with his journey by freezing up his only means of transportation up this valley before the end of October, nearly three weeks sooner than the usual time and Santa Claus and all his supplies were stalled at the mouth of the river. The children were in despair, but I said to them, "Santa Claus will be here all right," and I started the candy factory working overtime. They thought it was almost a miracle when part of the Christmas cargo arrived a week ahead of time and a fine big bundle was sent down from Mrs. (Rev.) J. B. McCullagh, of Aiyansh, so that we had more than enough, and we had to hang a baby tree from the ceiling. Ah! was not that sight a cure for any heartbreak! The dolls, bugles, swords, dishes, musical boxes, handkerchiefs, scarfs, muffs, candies, nuts, raisins, dates, gladsome hearts and happy faces.
S. W. Pollard, the head chief of the village, has been a most hospitable friend. We have enjoyed many a good meal with him, prepared by his estimable wife, Naks Wee-shakes. He is very sick at present and it grieves us sorely. Our daily prayer for him is that he may be restored to health and strength and enjoy the comfort of the Holy Ghost.

Paul Zalu did the handsome thing when the people returned from their summer's work at the canneries in September. They arrived late in the afternoon after a hard two days' trip by canoe up river. Paul presented them all with some fresh salmon which he had just caught and invited them all to supper. Paul's body is inhabited by the spirit of a great chief.

A number of the stalwarts went on a four days' hunting trip in October and returned with 20 mountain sheep and everybody shared in the trophies of the chase. There was feasting until we were ashamed to look at a leg of mutton.

Johnny O'Yea killed a fine big black bear and we were all invited to partake of a savoury bear stew. There is no better brand of hospitality than that produced by these Indian people.

IF THE DEAD CHIEFS COULD SPEAK!

If the chiefs of the past generation could advise the living they would very likely speak in the following strain: The conditions of life are rapidly changing in your valley, dear children. They began to change years ago with us, but we set our faces against it and were blind to the good which we now see the changes were bringing to us. We are glad to see that you continue to fish and hunt and follow the customs of the past, where they do not conflict with the teaching of the Word of God, but be wise, and add to your life's activities by learning how to make your gardens, how to keep sickness away, persuade your children to learn how to live under changing conditions.

Our hearts grieve for Patrick in the loss of his wife; for Samuel and Paul in the taking away of little Sophia; and for all the sick and suffering of the village.

We challenge the world to produce a happier Xmas party than that which gathered in the hospitable home of Rev. J. B. and Mrs. McCullagh, of Aiyansh. The party was limited in number, but England, Ireland, Canada and the United States were represented by three generations of jolly humanity.

NOTES AND OBSERVATIONS.

All the men turned out on Dec. 20 and with axes, saws and sleighs soon cut up and hauled into the building yard our first supply of wood. Breakfast and dinner were generously served to the workers by Anna, Elizabeth and Jenny.

The seats for the church have been ordered and have been sent. Miss Miller says that the early freeze up has made it impossible for us to bring them up river until the spring. We hope that the friends of this mission will see that we have more than the seats to bring up.

We have had no mail since October 1st and there 503 newspapers awaiting a mail carrier to be brought in by way of Kitimaatinah, Aiyansh and Gwinnsha. There is no mail service yet for these upper river settlements and we need one badly. While settlement continues in and around are arranging the distribution of which is too great importance to be set aside for five months and that cannot be satisfactorily dealt with by the telegraph or telephone, which have now reached Aiyansh.

Building operations are brisk in the settlement. Paul is building a new house. William has finished and nicely papered the inside of his; Jacob has newly painted his front room and improved his veranda; Johnny has remodelled his dwelling place and we are particularly pleased with the inside of his dwelling; Peter has made his house more comfortable; Henry is making good progress in the erection of his fine new residence; improvements are being made to the main schoolhouse church, and the cemetery is prepared cleared ground for next season's gathering.

The school teacher spent his Christmas holidays at Aiyansh, printing this little magazine. Rev. J. B. McCullagh very kindly put his small printing outfit at our disposal and we are grateful for his kindness. It for every copy of this little leaflet will give as much pleasure to our friends and helpers as the printing of it has given to us, it will be a very valuable Christmas gift to the Indians. It will be our diligent endeavor if every copy makes a friend for the mission and it would be a pleasant surprise to Mr. McCullagh if some of his newspaper friends would subscribe for copies of his printing which was destroyed by fire in September, 1910. He had a job office well equipped for the mission magazine and job work at a cost of $1,600. The Indians subscribed $65 towards a new outfit and $100 added to that is all he has been able to spare to renew the plant.

Dear Sir,

Is the Indian Department making a collection of Indian curios? Or if not is there any museum in Canada that you know of that is doing so? I have an opportunity of buying many old and peculiar relics of past Indian life. Horn spoons, Indian doctor's re-galia and paraphernalia, Indian dancing costumes, stone axes, masks and other things. These are worthy of being preserved.

Winter is over on the Prairies. We have had a very mild winter. Only two cold spells of about two weeks each. Very little snow. For the past two weeks the record has been "Frosty nights, bright..."
I have taken the liberty of addressing this letter to you personally as you requested in June last.

I am also enclosing a copy of the Manitoba Pioneer, our little mission magazine of which I am very proud and from which I hope great things.

Yours truly,

W. Allyc

The fall term of the Gwinotha day school was closed on Friday, Dec. 22, with a Christmas tree entertainment, and oh, my! if all those who contributed articles with which to decorate the tree could have been present to see the delight the event gave to all the people in the village they would have been repaid ten-fold. Santa Claus has become the jolly St. Nicholas of these Indian children as he does of all children wherever he goes. Willing hands helped to decorate the school room with three large mottoes—"A Merry Christmas," "Happy New Year," and "Glory to God in the Highest." They also made paper flowers and ribbons displaying the national colors and other ornaments, which made the school room look like fairy land. The boys went out and got a fine large spruce tree, almost a perfect cone. We notified those whom we knew would be delighted to help to make the hearts of these Indian children glad during the happiest season in all the year early in October that we were expecting Santa Claus to entertain the school. There was a hearty response, but alas Jack Frost seriously interfered with his journey by freezing up his only means of transportation up this valley before the end of October, nearly three weeks sooner than the usual time and Santa Claus and all his supplies were stalled at the mouth of the river. The children were in despair, but I said to them, "Santa Claus will be here all right," and I started the candy factory working overtime. They thought it was almost a miracle when part of the Christmas cargo arrived a week ahead of time and a fine big bundle was sent down from Mrs. (Rev.) J. B. McCullagh, of Aiyansh, so that we had more than enough, and we had to hang a baby tree from the ceiling. Ah! was not that sight a cure for any heartbreak! The dolls, bugles, swords, dishes, musical boxes, handkerchiefs, scarfs, muffs, candies, nuts, raisins, dates, gladsome hearts and happy faces.
S. W. Pollard, the head chief of the village, has been a most hospitable friend. We have enjoyed many a good meal with him, prepared by his estimable wife, Naks Wee-shakes. He is very sick at present and it grieves us sorely. Our daily prayer for him is that he may be restored to health and strength and enjoy the comfort of the Holy Ghost.

Paul Zalu did the handsome thing when the people returned from their summer's work at the canneries in September. They arrived late in the afternoon after a hard two days' trip by canoe up river. Paul presented them all with some fresh salmon which he had just caught and invited them all to supper. Paul's body is inhabited by the spirit of a great chief.

A number of the stalwarts went on a four days' hunting trip in October and returned with 20 mountain sheep and everybody shared in the trophies of the chase. There was feasting until we were ashamed to look at a leg of mutton.

Johnny O'Yea killed a fine big black bear and we were all invited to partake of a savoury bear stew. There is no better brand of hospitality than that produced by these Indian people.

IF THE DEAD CHIEFS COULD SPEAK!

If the chiefs of the past generation could advise the living they would very likely speak in the following strain: The conditions of life are rapidly changing in your valley, dear children. They began to change years ago with us, but we set our faces against it and were blind to the good which we now see the changes were bringing to us. We are glad to see that you continue to fish and hunt and follow the customs of the past, where they do not conflict with the teaching of the Word of God, but be wise, and add to your life's activities by learning how to make your gardens, how to keep sickness away, persuade your children to learn how to live under changing conditions.

Our hearts grieve for Patrick in the loss of his wife; for Samuel and Paul in the taking away of little Sophia; and for all the sick and suffering of the village.

We challenge the world to produce a happier Xmas party than that which gathered in the hospitable home of Rev. J. B. and Mrs. McCullagh, of Aiyannah. The party was limited in number, but England, Ireland, Canada and the United States were represented by three generations of jolly humanity.

NOTES AND OBSERVATIONS.

All the men turned out on Dec. 20 and with axes, saws and sleighs soon cut up and hauled into the school yard our winter's supply of wood. Breakfast and dinner were generously served to the workers by Amelia, Elizabeth and Jennie.

The seats for the church have been ordered and have arrived at Mill Bay, but the early freeze up has made it impossible for us to bring them down river before spring. We hope that the friends of this mission will see that we need more than the seats to bring up.

We have had no mail since October, and there is 500 pounds now awaiting a mail carrier to be brought by way of Kitamaatinak and Aiyannah to Gwaihok. There is no mail service yet for these up river settlements and we need one badly. What settlement is coming in and questions are arising the discussion of which is of no great importance to her mind; for five weeks and that cannot be satisfactorily dealt with by the telegraph or telephone, which have now reached Aiyannah.

Building operations are brisk in the settlement. Paul is building a new house. Weskeetum has remodelled and nicely painted his new house. Jacob has newly painted his thatch room and improved his verandah; Johnny has remodelled his verandah and warmly partitioned off the inside of his dwelling. Peter has built a house and is comfortably housed. Many good progress in the erection of his fine new residence; improvements are being made to the mission house and church and most everybody is preparing cleared places for new houses.

The school teacher spent his Christmas holidays at Aiyannah printing this little magazine. Rev. J. B. McCullagh very kindly put his small printing outfit at our disposal for the benefit of the Indians. We feel sure that the result of this experiment will give us much pleasure to our friends and helpers as the printing of it has given to us, it will be a very valuable Christmas gift to the Indians many of whom will be our guests. It would be every child makes a fortune for the mission and it would be a pleasant surprise to Mr. McCullagh if some of his newspaper friends would respond to some extent his printing offer, which was made last year by first September, 1910. He had a job office well equipped for the mission magazine and job work at a cost of $1,600. The Indians subscribed $65 towards a new outfit and $100 added to that is all he has been able to spare to renew the plant.

On September 30th arrived at Gwinoha at 8 P.M., W.A. Myers met us on arrival and we accompanied him to his house or shack, where we had a general discussion on school and other matters effecting the general welfare of the Indian people.

W.A. MYERS' HOUSE.

This building is what we would call a shack and was bought by Myers and is occupied by him. The building is not palatial in any respect, having but one large room with woodshed attached, and the floor being laid with rough lumber.

Mr. Myers had everything clean and there was not the slightest trace of any disagreeable smell. In one corner he had his bed, and with wash basin, cooking stove, heating stove and other furniture, made by himself, occupied about one half of the room. The other half he used for the Indian schoolchildren.

WOODSHED.

On examining the woodshed closely I found that in one corner he had what we might call a dry earth closet with a hole cut through the floor, and an excavation in the ground of two or three feet with a box placed therein. With a bag of slacked lime and the ashes from the stove he was able to keep the place quite clean and without any disagreeable odor. As reported to the Department that the place was in a filthy bad smelling condition, it is impossible to comprehend. I cross-questioned Mr. Myers about the report and he explained that during his absence last summer, being called away hurriedly down the river by an Indian from Aiyansh, he did not have time to clean up the place and on account of some of the Indians having Oolichan oil.

Sir,

I have the honour to transmit herewith the enclosed requisition for school material for the Qwinaha Indian Day School. During my trip up the Nass River this fall, I inspected the Indian church building used for school purposes and made arrangements with Mr. Paul Mercer, the native teacher, to re-open school in October as soon as the people returned to the village. My visit to the village was made on the 25th of September.

The operation of this school is not entirely satisfactory partly owing to the fact that it is impossible to give the teacher any personal supervision during the winter months when the Nass River is closed to navigation. Nevertheless, I believe Paul Mercer, who has not the same advantages as a trained teacher, is doing his best under the circumstances. The small number of children at this village did not warrant the appointment of a white teacher and rather than allow the children to grow up without any education, it was decided to appoint the present teacher, who would be able to impart, at least, an elementary education and teach the children how to read and write.

The whole arrangement being only a temporary one, I have not recommended any expenditure for desks or other school furniture until a more satisfactory and permanent building can be provided either by the Department or the people themselves.

Your obedient servant,

Indian Agent.

My dear Sir,

I have on this mail received intimation that it is the intention of Mrs. John Foster, who has been teaching at Gauyen City since the inception of the school, to resign.

This is a matter of some concern to me, as Mrs. Foster has always been reliable, but, of course, I am anxious to replace her with someone suitable for this work. However you will understand how difficult it is for us to send a qualified teacher in on the grant now being allowed this place.

Will you advise me as to what might be done, or if there is any possibility of our having an increased grant or a teacher's salary as is allowed at Glen Vowell.

I am anxious to immediately take this matter up with our Headquarters at Toronto, asking that we have a qualified teacher at this place, but feel I must be able to definitely place before them all particulars, as there is little time for an exchange of correspondence, and as territorial changes have just been made, it may be difficult for us to get the right person if we have not plenty of time.

I have previously taken the matter of increased grant with Mr. Collison, but he argued that she was in Ottawa not as a teacher, but as a missionary. I distinctly stated that she went in solely as a teacher, and that my religious work which she might do on Sunday was of her own choice. We had been promised to send in a teacher as they had no school.

I understand that Mrs. Foster has already written Mr. Collison and stated that we would not be able to supply a qualified teacher, and that he has sent her letter on to Ottawa for consideration. I regret that she wrote this without referring first to us, as if the grant can be increased to compare with other schools in the same circumstances, we will do our best to appoint a suitable person.

Any advice which you might give me will be greatly appreciated.

Assuming you of our desire to cooperate with you in the uplifting of the Natives, I am,

Yours faithfully,

Sir:-

I beg to inform the Department of the resignation of Mrs. Foster, teacher of the Gwinaha Indian Day School, Nass river. Copies of correspondence relative to a request for an increased salary for the teacher of this school are attached.

As the Department is aware the Gwinaha school is a small one, having a total of 15 pupils and an average attendance of 10 during the past year.

Mrs. Foster (then Miss Alice Keeney) was appointed by the Salvation Army in 1930 as a missionary school teacher. She was allowed by the Department an assisted salary amounting to $50.00 per month for ten teaching months, plus $10.00 per month paid from the school vote for dispensing simple medicines to the Indians, making a total salary of $600.00 per year.

Mrs. Foster was not a qualified teacher. Should the services of another teacher nominated by the Salvation Army be sanctioned by the Department at a salary in line with that given to other small schools, I would recommend that the teacher appointed be properly qualified as I do not think it fair that the Department should be called upon to pay the salaries of missionaries who are not qualified to teach school.

Your obedient servant,

Dear Sir:

I am informed in a letter addressed to the Inspector of Schools by Brigadier W.J. Carruthers of the Salvation Army, Wrangell, Alaska, that there has been some delay by the Department in giving approval in the case of the nomination of Mrs. Suddaby, Nee Miss Florence L. Thompson, as teacher of the Gwinaha Indian Day School, Skeena River Agency.

I understand that the fact that she is now married and that her husband is physically fit to support her has made it difficult for the Department to approve of the appointment of Mrs Suddaby as teacher of the above named school.

Inspector Barry points out that (Captain) Suddaby of the S.A. is going to Gwinaha or Canyon City as a missionary, and that such cases are different from those in which the husband is well able to support his wife, a former teacher, in which the usual practice is that the girl gives up her teaching work on marriage.

On September 9th last (Captain) and Mrs Suddaby called on Inspector Barry here, and were informed by him that we had no confirmation of their appointment or approval for them to proceed to take up the positions for which their Church had nominated them at Canyon City. Inspector Barry however gave them all the help he could with regard to the classroom work that would be required and wrote on the 10th of September to Indian Agent Collison with regard to his interview with these people.

I am informed by Inspector Barry that Mrs Suddaby was trained in the Regina Normal School in 1929-30 and holds an interim certificate in Saskatchewan and in Alberta, but has no B.C. qualifications. Her total experience extends to a little over two years, mainly in Alberta. Her inspector's reports are not very satisfactory though for a beginner indicate that with training the girl might train later into a successful teacher.

I am informed that she did not impress Inspector Barry as a very good candidate for the vacant Gwinaha position.
It appears from Brigadier Carruthers' letter that it would be most difficult to find a qualified teacher in the Salvation Army who would be available at this late date to go to the Gwinaha Indian Day School.

Under the circumstances, and after discussing the matter with Inspector Barry, I would recommend that Mrs. Suddaby be appointed as temporary teacher of the Gwinaha Indian Day School for the period October 1st to May 31st, 1939.

I believe that the authorities of the Salvation Army should be informed that, while under the circumstances this nomination is being approved by the Department, it is not considered that Mrs. Suddaby holds the necessary B. C. qualifications and that such appointment can only be of a strictly temporary nature, with the provision that a teacher with acceptable B. C. qualifications be nominated to take Mrs. Suddaby's place for the academic year 1939-40.

In conclusion may I point out that Inspector Barry, in his last report on the Gwinaha Indian Day School forwarded to the Department under my file 15/48930 on May 17th, 1937, recommended that the School be only operated for eight months of each academic year, October 1st to May 31st. As there are hardly any pupils at Canyon City in September and June, it would be better not to attempt to operate a school there during these months.

I would ask that the Department's final decision with regard to the opening of the Gwinaha Indian Day School and the appointment of Mrs. Suddaby as teacher be sent to Indian Agent Collison by night lettergram.

Dear Sir:

I am in receipt of a copy of your letter of September 2 last addressed to Mr. W. E. Collison, Indian Agent, Prince Rupert, B. C.

The Department has recently decided to approve the appointment of Mrs. Suddaby as teacher of the Gwinaha School for the academic year 1938-39. It is understood, however, that other arrangements will have to be made for the academic year 1939-40.

In the first place our regulations do not favour the employment of married women whose husbands are in a position to support them and in the second place I understand that Mrs. Suddaby does not possess British Columbia qualifications. In view of the fact that there are so many fully qualified teachers out of employment at the present time I think you will realize how difficult it is for us to justify the appointment of teachers who do not possess the requisite academic qualifications.

I am also informed by Indian Commissioner MacKay that a great majority of the Indians are not on the Reserve during the months of June and September. Under these circumstances I am advised that it would be in the best interests of all parties concerned to only conduct the school for an eight-month period; namely, from October 1 to May 31. In nominating a teacher to take charge of this school for the academic year 1939-40 please be guided by the fact that the Gwinaha School will only be in operation, during the academic year 1939-40, from October 1 to May 31.

Dear Sir: Re GWINAHA SCHOOL, NASS RIVER, B.C.

Seeing we are nearing the end of the present school term I am writing you with reference to the re-appointment of Mrs. Captain Suddaby, for the 1939-40 term.

From reports I have received from Gwinaha, and from personal observations, Mrs. Suddaby has filled the position as teacher very acceptably this last year.

The natives have co-operated with the school and the attendance has been very good considering the coming and going of these people in their hunting and trapping.

Captain Suddaby has given very good service in our Mission at Gwinaha, and the natives are anxious that Captain and Mrs. Suddaby remain for a longer term.

I will be glad if you will take the matter up with Captain Barry the Inspector, and with the Department at Ottawa. I hope that you have been as favorably impressed as I have with the work of these officers.

You will realize we have been to considerable expense placing them at Gwinaha, as I hope it will not be necessary to make any change for the coming year.

Thanking you for your interest in this school and for your co-operation in all matters for the betterment of the Indians in your Agency, I am,

Yours faithfully,

Dear Sir:

With reference to the second paragraph in your letter No. 15/8/2667 of June 20th, I would say that my only reason for writing the Salvation Army directly was in response to the personal request from Brigadier Gillingham. On April 26th the Brigadier called at the office and stated that Captain and Mrs. Suddaby desired a transfer and asked that after I had visited them at Canyon City I write and give him my reaction to the situation. I found the Suddabys emphatic in voicing their desire for a change. I considered, therefore, that it would be better for them to move rather than return and be dissatisfied and lose interest in their work.

If any question of school management had been involved I would naturally have reported this to the Commissioner only, and directly. In this case, however, it was simply and entirely a case of desire for a transfer from the Suddabys themselves on which the Brigadier had asked for my opinion.

I advised Captain Suddaby when at Canyon City that if they intended to leave, the Department would require a resignation. This has now come to hand and is herewith attached.

I beg to forward herewith a copy of a letter received from Mr. Indian Agent Gillett regarding the attendance at the Gwinaha Indian Day School. The teacher at this little school is Captain Haddlund.

It will be observed that the departure of four families from the Reserve will reduce the number of children available to attend to five. Under these circumstances, it would appear that we should either close the school at the end of the first half of the current school year or allow the school to continue in session on the understanding that for the balance of the academic year the teacher would receive not more than $70.00 per month from the Department. In view of the fact that the parents remaining on the Reserve are anxious for the school to remain open and are prepared to contribute to the teacher's salary to the extent mentioned by Mr. Gillett and, also, that the drop in the attendance will be due to the parents of some of the children accepting employment in war work away from the Reserve, I am inclined to favour the latter alternative and would recommend that this arrangement be approved.

D.M. MacKay,
Indian Commissioner for B.C.

Major D.M. MacKay, Indian Commissioner for B.C., Vancouver, B.C.

RE: Gwinaha (Canyon City) School.

On October 24th I visited the above named school. Up to that date, there had been eight children who had actually put in appearance at the school and who were present at the time of my visit. The number that should attend is twelve.

Four families will be leaving Gwinaha Reserve and will be working either at Prince Rupert or Port Edward. They will be away until spring when they may return just to plant their gardens. There will not be more than five children at this school from November on. It was pointed out to the people, that, in view of this fact, the Department may consider it advisable to dispense of the services of a teacher. Rather than have this happen, the people suggested that they would pay $20.00 per month towards the teacher's salary.

I have since interviewed Brigadier Gillingham of the Salvation Army and he states that, while the Headquarters of the church do not favour the idea of having an officer with so few people, he did not think they would move him this year. He also stated that the $20.00 reduction would not cause any embarrassment to the teacher, Captain Haddlund, even if the Indians did not pay the $20.00 monthly, as it appears that the teacher's cheque is passed on to the church which in turn pays him approximately $70.00 a month.

Under these circumstances, I consider the Department would be justified in reducing his salary.

J. Gillett,

Ottawa, August 10th, 1933.

Sir,

I beg to acknowledge the receipt of your 7-E-6258 of the 31st ultimo, advising the Department of the resignation of Mrs. Foster, teacher of the Gwimaha Indian Day School. In reply I beg to say that her resignation is accepted.

It appears from the correspondence forwarded with your letter that it will not be possible to secure a qualified teacher for the amount we have been allowing, viz., $60 a month, less 10%. The Department agrees that there is not much value in employing unqualified teachers. At the same time, owing to a recent ruling of the Treasury Board, it is not possible for the Department to increase the salary at this school during the current fiscal year. Ottawa, February 25th, 1947.

Mr. F. Earl Anfield, Indian Agent,
Prince Rupert, B.C.

With reference to your letter of the 14th inst., the Department approves the purchase of the under-mentioned articles in order to supply a hot drink to the children attending the Gwinaha Indian Day School.

25 lbs. of cocoa
50 lbs. of sugar
2 cases of canned milk.

Bernard F. Neary,
Supt. of Welfare & Training.
Department of Mines & Resources, Indian Affairs Branch,
Ottawa.

In a report received from A. J. Walker, teacher of the Gwinaha Indian Day School, he states as follows:

"After the Christmas holidays the weather turned very cold and miserable, our children were running home during recess to get a hot drink so I thought that it would be a better idea if I were to make a pot of cocoa every day and serve it to them in the school during the morning, thus keeping them warm and satisfied. This has proved very satisfactory as it has also done away with them returning from their homes late for the next session and everybody seems quite happy about it. Now I understand that the Indian Department will provide this when necessary, therefore I am wondering if you will get the ration board to send me up sufficient sugar coupons to see me through till the end of March. There are sixteen children getting the benefit of this idea."

Authority is requested to purchase the following supplies to enable this health measure to be continued:

- 25 lbs. of cocoa
- 50 lbs. of sugar
- 2 cases of canned milk.

The weather on the Naas River this winter has been very severe with temperatures as low as 32° below zero. I am sure that this action on the part of this teacher will help to maintain good health at this little village.

F. Earl Anfield,
Indian Agent.

Following receipt of information from the teacher of the Gwinaha Indian Day School that some articles had been provided for use at the teacher's residence, I wrote to Mr. Indian Agent Anfield for details for our files. My very dear Sir,

I want to remind you of your promise to see us through with a school-house this spring. Mr. Whittington has just left Fortitamaat from here urged me to immediately write you.

A School-house has become altogether imperative. Think of 27 Indian children in our little Mission Room for from 4 to 5 hours every day for upwards 2 weeks. Last quarter as you will see from the Register our average was 22-20. May I say that this exceedingly high average was not easily obtained or maintained but by carefully following up the children & the parents by thoughtful handling of them when they came. I believe we have done almost as good as was to be expected under existing conditions.

And I am confident you are not willing that I should have to continue to teach under such insanitary circumstances. You are prepared to do all you can to strengthen my hands. I am already indebted to you for many kindnesses shown. So I briefly yet most earnestly ask you to do your best to secure me at your very earliest convenience.

1st a sufficiency for substantial School-house
2nd ... to furnish same.

I am inclined to think there will be even a greater number of children coming to school next year. I would suggest $600 as a suitable cost of house. And anything from $50 - $100 to build furnish it. Please let me know very earliest moment when money will be available, as we
want to get it immediately fixed up.

The people have promised to give us care back of the Church.

We await your presence to have the agreement. At present
the people are away hunting - but will be back in April.

I trust you are well of family. Am glad to say we are

Our very kindest regards

Sincerely Yours

Special Report in accordance with Departmental Letter 4-210 dated January 14, 1931, and attached to my Report on the Hartley Bay Indian Day School.

In accordance with the instructions issued to me by the Department of Indian Affairs, I am forwarding this special report for the information of the Superintendent of Indian Education.

I beg to state that I do not consider the services of Mr. James Oliver, at present teacher of the Hartley Bay Indian Day School, to be satisfactory. I have therefore requested that he be removed from his position at the above school at the earliest possible moment.

In my opinion Mr. Oliver is far too old to carry on the teaching work at this point, and owing to his lack of any professional training at a Normal School, is unable to give satisfactory service as a teacher in the above mentioned school. The present state of things at the Hartley Bay Indian Day School are set out in my report, and show a deplorable condition.

The matter of the removal of the present teacher was brought up in a conference at Prince Rupert a short time ago, by the Rev A. Barner of the United Church of Canada.

Should the Department agree to the course I have here suggested, a suitable teacher to fill a vacancy at Hartley Bay can easily be suggested from the list of selected candidates in this office.

Gerald H. Barry,
District Inspector of Indian Schools, B.C.

EXTRACT from Inspector Barry's Report regarding his visit to the HARTLEY BAY INDIAN DAY SCHOOL on May 16th, 1932.

Original on File 168-28-6.

Name:- Mr. James Oliver. Age 68.

Salary:- $950 - The United Church gives $900.00 of this to the teacher. No doubt, the difference is placed as rent of the Mission House. He also gets $100.00 per annum as Post Master.

Qualifications:- M. A. Sidney University. Barrister at Law in N. S. Wales; First Class Honour Certificate as teacher in Nebraska. He never went to a Normal School, holds no certificate valid in Canada. This teacher has had 22 years experience in teaching, including 9 years at Hartley Bay.

Health is stated to be good. Had bad influenza lately (?) Was operated on for hernia at Bella Bella six years ago.

Success:- Has no idea whatever of modern teaching. The school if I am to judge from the few children present is not properly graded. Conditions HOPELESS.

Nothing whatever could be done for this man. He is far too old to learn how to teach. He is perfectly useless in his present position.

The children use slates and the small children have no exercise books. I told the teacher he must obtain the prescribed Writing Manuals for all the children. The work of this school, if it can be called work, is not properly graded. There is no Course of Study available in the school. I believe that the teacher has an old one in his own home.

Register:- This was not completed as to the quarterly averages, etc., so these cannot be quoted. In other respects the register was well kept.

General: It is quite hopeless to report in any greater detail with regard to the work or lack of work of the children. I quite fail to understand why this man has been permitted to stay here as a teacher for so long. It is only fair to add that the Rev. A. Barner requested me to visit the school, as he considered a change necessary. In this I quite agree. I could do nothing whatever for this poor old man. He even had to go over to his own house to get some chalk for me to use in the schoolroom.

Reverend Sir:

I am in receipt of your letter of July 8th in reply to my 15/25462, dated June 28th.

With regard to your second paragraph, I may say that Mrs. Snodgrass, the teacher of the Indian Day School at Bella Coola, is at present attending my course of lectures at the Provincial Summer School for Teachers in Victoria. Mrs. Snodgrass is making every effort to become acquainted with the better methods now being used in rural schools. While I am still of the opinion that Mrs. Snodgrass is not in good health and that it would be much better to have a younger and better trained teacher at Bella Coola, I am in full agreement with both the Department of Indian Affairs and yourself that it is now much too late to dispense with Mrs. Snodgrass' services before the end of the next school year in January 1933. In any case I shall not have an opportunity of again inspecting her school before the spring of next year. Beyond warning this teacher that the report of the last inspection on her school was not considered satisfactory, I would recommend that no further action be taken until I have had an opportunity of again reporting to the Department on the Bella Coola Indian Day School.

With regard to the case of Mr. James Oliver, the teacher of the Hartley Bay Indian Day School, I regret to say that I see no reason to in any way modify my report to the Department on this teacher. It is absolutely essential that the services of Mr. Oliver as a teacher in the Indian schools be terminated at the first possible opportunity. I agree with you that as Mr. Oliver has proceeded for his location, believing that he would be returning to work in the Hartley Bay School on the 1st September, nothing further can be done with regard to replacing him before the end of the present calendar year. There can, however, be no doubt that Mr. Oliver is utterly unsuitable as a teacher of young children and I would advise that one of the specially selected candidates now on my list of applicants or in attendance at the Provincial Summer School, be selected to replace him as from January 1st, 1933.

I regret very much that it was not possible to report to the Department on these teachers at an earlier date. The work in the office has so greatly increased during the past year that I am now four or five weeks behind hand with my reports. The correspondence is increasing daily and there is a constant stream of applicants for personal interviews as well.

Dear Mr. Barry:

Your letter of June 26th, addressed to our Mr. Berner, has been received in his absence on a visit to some of our Indian Missions in Northern Manitoba. It is unlikely that Mr. Berner will be back in the office before the end of August, and in the meantime I shall be responsible for the administration of any matters that occur in connection with our Indian work. We shall be looking forward to receiving your letter with recommendations for appointments to our schools where there are vacancies.

I am in receipt of letters from the Department at Ottawa, in which they state that you have decided that the services of Mrs. Snodgrass at Bella Coola and of Mr. James Oliver, M.A., at Hartley Bay, are unsatisfactory. It is not quite clear whether it is your intention that these teachers should be dismissed forthwith or not. I have seen that after having visited most of these places on the Pacific coast last summer, I am quite inclined to agree with you in regard to both of these teachers. The difficulty is - especially in the case of Mr. Oliver - that they have served the Department and the Church to the best of their ability over a long period of years; and they have closed school and gone on vacation with the full expectation of returning to work the 1st of September. The financial situation is such that there is no hope at so late a date of their being able to obtain employment this fall. The plan which was followed in the case of Miss Morrise, who was given six months' notice, is very much more in harmony with the principles under which we ordinarily approach such changes in personnel. While I would be very glad to think that we had younger and more competent teachers in these two schools, I am wondering if we might not allow Mrs. Snodgrass and Mr. Oliver to carry on at least to the end of the school year. I feel quite sure that there would be no difficulty in your obtaining quite satisfactory teachers for the opening of school after the Christmas vacation. As a matter of fact, throughout the rest of Canada we have never had teachers of as high a calibre applying for work in Indian Schools as at the present time.

Assuring you that we appreciate your co-operation and are very sincerely desirous of bringing our Indian schools up to the full standard of the Public School system in British Columbia.

I am

Yours very sincerely,

"Kenneth J. Beaton"

Dear Sir,-

In response to your request for information as to what our Board has done in regard to the teacher at Hartley Bay, I may say that following my letter of July 5th, I wrote Mr. James Oliver, who has been the teacher there for a number of years, telling him of our correspondence with Captain Barry and with the Department. I told him that originally it was Captain Barry's intention that he should not be re-engaged for the present school term but that we had proceeded on his behalf, in view of his long service with the Department, and it was mutually agreed that he should continue until December 31st. Dear Sir;

The following is a report of my absence from conducting school on December 23rd and the morning of 24th.

"On the afternoon of Dec. 23rd, 1939, Mr. and Mrs. Len Weaver arrived here with their boat. I fully expected them ashore to visit us but a short time after their arrival I was called from the house and told that there was something amiss on the boat. Upon reaching the boat I found that Mr. Weaver had collapsed.

In spite of all we could do, it was impossible to revive him. He had been engaged in buying furs and besides a supply of these he had also a large sum of money on the boat.

Mrs. Weaver was prostrated so it was necessary that I take charge. I knew that a report would have to be made to the Police authorities and in addition to this was the fact that the deceased was a very close friend. These reasons caused me to decide that it would be in the best interests of all if I made the trip to Prince Rupert with the body.

This I did and after having completed all arrangements, returned to Hartley Bay at noon on Dec. 24th.

J. A. Findlay

The Deputy Superintendent of Indian Affairs,

Dear Sir,

On my return from vacation in the summer of 1932, I was greatly surprised to learn from a letter of the United Church of Canada's Department of Home Missions, which I found awaiting me, that my services as Indian School teacher at Hartley Bay No. 6 were to be immediately dispensed with, by reason of the Indian Schools' inspectors recent report to the Indian Department, to the effect that the state of Hartley Bay Indian Bay School was very unsatisfactory. In addition to this, I gathered from some rather vague remarks in the letter that my lack of a Canadian diploma (without which, I may indicate here, I had worked under your Department for 22 years, during which I had held a First Class School Diploma from the Education Department of the State of Nebraska W. J. C.) and the fact of my being no longer a young man were further reasons for your Department's action. The Home Mission Department added that it had thoroughly
The Indian Department's extremely annoying procedure, and as a result had secured the assurance that I should retain my position until the end of 1832. I need hardly say that I deeply resented the suspicion as both ignorantly inaccurate and unjust (to characterize it as no worse) and in any Quarterly Report in September 1832 I denounced it, with the assurance that I would deal with it at a more convenient season. I did not further trouble. I decided to defer all comment till my connection with the Indian Department should be ended, so that any failure during my further tenure of the position of teacher might be avoided.

The past two months have been so occupied with settling my affairs in Canada, and removing here, and settling down in London that it is only now I can fulfill the above promise, which I should on no account avoid keeping. My remaining for a further period, till June 1833, on the failure of the measure to secure a successor to me in December 1832, has nothing to do with the subject save to show the reason of my long silence.

In May 1831 your Inspector visited Shortly days. He asked me certain formal questions as to my status as a teacher. His manner was as cordial and affable as a plain-clothes police officer in making an arrest. Then he inspected the school (save the walls!) if one can call such a performance an inspection.
There were but 5 scholars present—of 7, 8, 8, 9 and 13 years of age respectively—-the first or nearly so better than beginners, though their signatures of residence on or absence from the Reserve; the last a scholar of only fair mentality. The inspector seemed to ignore any explanation that some of scholars, the best in the school, were away gathering edible seaweed, which kept them the best of a meal to do. They followed this custom during my 10 years' stay on the Reserve, and had done it before I came there. Unquestioned; but the inspector evidently set it down as merely ordinary bad attendance; though for 10 years I protested against it, and reported it every year. Four of these scholars had never seen an inspector; but he handed scraps of paper as questionnaires to children as familiar with their form of examination as with Egyptian hieroglyphics. He did everything very quickly; for he was all the time "on the job" to get done. His inspection in all subjects lasted about 20 minutes; the rest of the time was taken up in an account of his achievements among the New Canada Indians (children of foreign origin); but he evidently didn't know that there are cleverer, and more energetic, and ambitious by far, in intellectual work than the ordinary children) and in working out a lengthy list of test and exercise results; for in all, his time here was only between one and two hours.
I am anxious to end this letter. The burden of his report was unsatisfactory. I want to give you the impression he himself made on the teacher, or careful observation. I set him down as a man with a thin veneer of education, a pruner in trees, or a kindergarten expert; a man without sympathy of any kind, and quite devoid of imagination; and as ignorant of the mentality, everyday facts, and defects of the Indians, generated by their natural environment, as he is of the capabilities of the people of this planet.

I have ever felt deeply humiliated to have to rank as a subordinate, during these many years, to men unfit to loose my own patches in knowledge, experience, culture, and intellectual ability. I cannot still more say humiliation in the exquisite statement of an intellectual nobody, and my dismissal after twenty-three years of most faithful, self-denying, and uncomplaining service as unworthy, but for the missionary Society's intervention, as if I had been some incapable degenerate.

When I left it the school was materially in a better state, and the children better disciplined, behaved, and taught than when I took charge ten years before; and in the process I had spent for building, bricks, lumber-material, and repairs at least two hundred dollars of my own money, without asking you for it; and I should not have asked for it even if you had not given me a retiring
cheque, for which I now thank you.

I have often thought the Indian Department (and some other Canadian institutions as well) ought to have written about its portals - all hope abandoned age who enter here; for in 23 years service I never received a word of commendation or appreciation from it.

The only thing of value in its eyes seems a Canadian diploma, which in other, civilian eyes is of little worth at all. The fact I was superior in academic honours to any man in your Department, or even, I might add, to any one the lists of your whole schools, counted for nothing. People elsewhere are much wiser than this and are not slow to observe.

I may add in closing the words used by one of the former undersecretaries in communicating the news of your death in August 1752: "In God's name how shall we repay you for all that you have done in the years gone by for us and our work among the Indian people."

Yours sincerely,

James Oliver.

With reference to Mr. Inspector Thorsteinsson's report on Hartley Bay School, the interior would look brighter, no doubt, if it had a new coat of paint, but it is just a question whether it is worth while to incur any expenses on an old building, particularly if a new school is to be erected within the next year or so. Memorandum:

Deputy Minister.

MR-IA9-93.

The permanent position of Constable, Indian Reserve, for the Skeena Agency, B.C., became vacant on June 1, 1943, on the retirement of Mr. Alfred John Watkinson, on account of ill health.

The vacancy was advertised in April, 1943, Competition No. 43-431, but no applications were received. Owing to war conditions, it was thought unlikely that anyone would be secured by re-advertisement of the position, and the Civil Service Commission advised the Department of its willingness to certify the appointment of any suitable person who could be secured locally. The position has remained vacant, although the need for additional assistance at the Skeena Agency is very apparent, not only for a Constable, but adequate office assistance, and the Indian Agent would welcome the appointment of a Constable, who, while not engaged in constable duties, would be able to assist him otherwise, in the agency work.

As the Indians leave for the fishing season, the Hartley Bay School is being closed with effect from June 1. It has been suggested by the Indian Agent, in which suggestion the Indian Commissioner concurs, that Mr. J. A. Findlay, the teacher at the Hartley Bay School be engaged as Constable and assistant to the Indian Agent.

Mr. Findlay, who has been employed as teacher since September 1, 1935, is paid salary at the rate of $95. per teaching month. He is also provided with living quarters. I have to refer to Mr. Neary's letter dated June 25th, 1947. Attached is a letter from Mr. Indian Agent Anfield in reply to an enquiry as to whether or not Mr. Cantelon expects to be paid for the months of May and June. In view of the circumstances set forth in Mr. Anfield's letter, and because it will be difficult to employ and retain teachers if their salaries are to be paid for only part of the normal school term, I recommend that Mr. Cantelon's salary be paid for both May and June.

With reference to Mr. Anfield's recommendation that the Hartley Bay School operate only from October 1st to May 30th; during this latter month there is a movement to Butedale, about 30 miles from Hartley Bay, of Indians who remain at that point until the fall.

I suggest that Mr. Anfield be asked to report on the advisability of using the teacher from Hartley Bay at Butedale, either to operate a school from May until October, or to do welfare work for that period. Re yours of July 5th, 1947, file 12-11-2, Rev. W. R. Cantelon and wife were taken from Hartley Bay to Butedale on the "Waskeena" on the 4th instant, from which point they proceeded to Bella Bella where the reverend gentleman is to become the Missionary.

Mr. Cantelon informed me that the last day on which school was held was April 28; that on April 29th the entire village moved to the seaweed camps. He remained, hoping they would return, or at least enough of them to re-open the school. Apart from one day when the people came back for a funeral, the Cantelons have been the sole occupants of the village.

Under the circumstances, I would presume that Rev. W. R. Cantelon would expect to be paid at least for the month of May.

In 1945, when Mr. J. A. Findlay was the teacher, the School was closed on April 23rd.

In 1944, the School closed on May 9th.

In 1943, the School closed on May 17th.

If Mr. Findlay was paid to the end of the quarter, the president should stand. I have no information as to whether or not he was paid. It is recommended that the school be closed as from May 30th in future and re-opened October 1st, unless in the opinion of the Department, the short term of 8 months would make it impossible to obtain a teacher.

Dear Sir,

The Post Office at Hartley Bay, B.C., was closed on the 23rd July 1945, as the Postmaster had to leave and as there was no other responsible white person available to take the position of Postmaster.

Application has been received for the reopening of the office from Mrs. Inez B. Tedlock who was to leave on the 13th September to assume the duties of school-teacher at the above point.

At the present time the population of Hartley Bay consists of 175 Indians.

Mrs. Tedlock is an employee of the Department of Indian Affairs and is not a British subject. The Department requires Canadian citizenship for appointment to all Postmasterships except where no other person is available and there is no alternative but to appoint a non-Canadian. Also an existing Order provides that persons should not be in receipt of salaries from two government Departments.

Would you be good enough to let the Department have your Minister's opinion and if a Post Office is required at the above point.

Yours truly,

Dear Sir:

The last of Oct., I received a check for $6 for janitor for month of Sept.; nothing has been received since. Would you please look into this?

There's another matter I'd like to inquire about. I knew nothing about having to dispense medicine, until upon arrival here. Have done it since Sept.; it really gives you no free time at all. It seems to me a person should receive some remuneration for this, also have to give out mail when it's brought in.
There is a woman here, whom I understand, has served as nurse for the entire village for many years; in fact, she's nurse and Doctor. I understand she's very competent. Imagine Dr. Mac Donald of Fort Simpson could give you more information about her than I can. She prescribes all medicines, why could not she dispense them also & receive some remuneration for same as well as for her nursing?
