Re: Hartley Bay School.

Mrs. Inez Tedlock, teacher at the Hartley Bay Indian Day School, arrived in Prince Rupert on Wednesday, March 3rd, 1948, having travelled with her husband in company with Rev. and Mrs. Peter Kelly on the M.S. "Thomas Crosby". Mrs. Tedlock was in a highly nervous condition and I advised her to stay in town for a rest.

Today I had a long conversation with Mr. and Mrs. Tedlock about conditions at Hartley Bay School. They felt that since Christmas the attitude of the people has changed towards them and that they no longer have the scholastic interests of their children at heart.

I believe these people would profit by a few more days rest and I have authorized them to remain in Prince Rupert until Friday of this week when I shall take them back to Hartley Bay and have a meeting with the Council about school conditions. I shall ask Mrs. Tedlock to see a Doctor whilst she is in town as a certificate of disability may be required to cover this absence.

Dear Sirs,

We are writing to you in connection with our pay checks. We are namely stationed at the Hartley Bay, B.C. Indian Reserve since Oct. 1948. During the year 1947-1948 we were at the Moose Woods Sioux Indian Reserve (Whitecap Indian Day School) Saskatchewan.

For this 1948-1949 school year we have received the following checks so far:

| Date       | Net Earning |
|------------|-------------|
| Oct.30,1948 | $167.60     |
| Nov.30,1948 | $84.60      |
| Dec.15,1948 | $83.00      |
| Dec.31,1948 | $84.60      |
| Jan.15,1949 | $83.00      |
| Jan.31,1949 | $84.60      |

What appears to be wrong is (1) the interim check ($2.00) is addressed to the Bank we do our business with, namely the Royal Bank of Canada at Langley Prairie, B.C. The Bank forwards these checks to us for endorsements before they receive them for deposit. (2) The stubs of the checks seem to be detached and come separately to us, usually first addressed to our former address at Moose Woods Reserve, in Saskatchewan, from where they are forwarded to us here at Hartley Bay. (3) You will notice that we miss one check, the interim check for November 1948. We have not received the check nor the stub for the same. Either it got lost in the mail which is quite likely under the circumstances, or else an error occurred at the Office of the Treasury in Ottawa where the checks are issued. Now what we would like to suggest for the future is:

Dear Mr. Morrow, not known my feelings toward the Indians is like your own. I simply wish to do the good, and that is why I have lived amongst them for the past eighteen years. I am a land swabber. I believe Mr. Whitington is going to speak to you on this subject when he comes north again.

To Mr. Geo.W.Horrow

Metlakatla, B.C.

Dear Friend:

I am writing this note to you by way of explanation. The people here as a whole want a proper school house built. I am sure that my heart is with them in this matter, seeing that I have been using a portion of my dwelling house for school purposes for the past nine years. Yes, and I went down very liberally on my own hands and knees with scrubbing brush etc., in order to keep the place neat. Dear friend, when you came here you saw the room I was using for school purposes, and I am sure you did agree with me when I say the place is not large enough to school 15 children in, and there is no dorms, but yet there will be an increase of four or five more this coming autumn. We have no room for writing desks.

Dear Friend, you know just how much land the people of this place have set aside for Mission Property, I think it is about 40 acres. St. and you know just how the buildings stand now on that land. It would not really be safe in case of fire to employ another good building inside such a small space. The people promised when you were here with Mr. Whittington that if ever the time came to erect a school house here, they would set a small piece of land aside for that purpose, in addition to what they had already set aside for the Mission Property. And now we all are in favour of erecting a school house, I asked them providing our Government and the Methodist Church together would find the material to build a proper school house here at Metlakatla Bay, seeing that you say you are too poor to do it. And yet you say you would like very much to have one built. Would you give a piece of land for that purpose as you promised to do? They are inclined to say they never promised the land. Dear Mr. Horrow, of course I would not argue the matter with them.

April 22nd

A.W. Vowell Esqre.

My dear Sir,

Please accept my heartiest thanks for your esteemed favor which came to hand today. It was exceedingly kind of you, Sir, to take all the trouble you did, & I only hope I may have the privilege some day of more practically expressing my great appreciation to you.

I am very sorry for the irregularity I made in forwarding direct to you the School Returns & Requisition for school Material. But it was only after having written the Indian Agent several times in vain that I made up my mind to write to you. For we have had a report Mr. Morrow has given up the Indian work, & I am inclined to believe it as he was always so prompt in replying to me. But I have been writing for over six weeks or two months & have received no reply as yet.

Our trouble is this, Sir, & it is no small one. We want most urgently a school house. Right up to the present the school has been held in the Indian room of the Mission. This room measures only 13x15. Last quarter our average was 14.55 and the one before this 21.21. For nearly 3 weeks we had from 23 - 27 children for from 4 to 5 hours every day (but Saturday) & this in itself contributes a certainly strong reason why we should have a school-house.

And then again our house is so dreadfully damp unless some change is made I shall lose both wife & children with consumption. Quite recently when we were retiring looking under the bed we saw some drops of water hanging from the mattress and spring. And this evidently had been the case for weeks. The result, as you may imagine, is my wife has contracted a cold that is not easily yielding to treatment.

I
I may say a school house has been already faithfully promised both by Dr. Whittington & Mr. Morrow. It was to be built this year. But owing to the retirement of Mr. Morrow—which we all most sincerely regret—and the impending retirement of the Rev. Dr. Whittington from the management of our Indian District, our work is most certainly suffering.

I intend to try the Agent again & see if he is at home. But if I am not worrying you too much I would be grateful to you if you could put in a word for us. We have had an exceptionally good two quarters here. I find improvement all along the line. The children are on the whole attentive, industrious & apt pupils. And their parents encourage us in every way. All we want is a good substantial school-house and furnishings. Granted this we can go on and prosper and will promise to be hereafter self-supporting so far school requisites are concerned.

I am asking for a $600. building, & $100. furnishings including school materials. Our village in the near future will be an important centre as the prospects of a railway coming & the opening of a new Saw-mill has attracted several new families.

I had several other matters I wished to bring before you but perhaps you would grant me an interview when I come down next week.

As I have but recently come out from England I am not very familiar with the right order of procedure in all these matters under your care. But if you can help us forward & secure us a hearing from the right source I will be ever grateful to you.

Yours very sincerely,

"H.W.W. Bromwich"

I will see the Returns are corrected & duly forwarded to the I. Agent.
British Columbia.

Sir,

The necessity for a new school building at Hartley Bay in your Agency has been brought to the attention of the Department and I have to ask you to be good enough to look into this matter and report fully. Sir,

In accordance with instructions received through the Indian Office at Victoria, B.C., I have the honor to renew applications for the erection of day schools at Kitkahtla, Port Essington and Hartley Bay, B.C.

I have also been instructed to send in plans, specifications, cost of freight, etc., in connection with these buildings. I have asked Mr. Agent Perry to send me the previous correspondence from the Metlakatla Office. Unless this correspondence contains plans, specifications, etc., asked for I don't see how I can supply the same without going to the various places to learn local conditions and to get the advice of an experienced carpenter. I have lately visited Port Essington and Hartley Bay, but did not go to Kitkahtla on account of its remoteness.

I have received from Rev. Mr. R. W. Gurd of Kitkahtla a plan for the proposed school there; he states that this school will cost $1500.00 as the village is off the regular steam-boat course, thus making both freight and
labor higher in price.

May I ask to get more particular instructions as to what the Department wishes me to do in connection with the erection of these buildings.

I am, Sir,

your obedient servant,

I have the honor to say visited Hartly Bay last March; at this time I was under the impression that plans etc. for these schools were amongst "Previous correspondence" at the Metlakatla Office.

There are Indian carpenters at Hartly Bay; a retired sea captain is living there; he told me that he might undertake to do the work; he owns a sawmill and has some rough lumber for sale.

Sir,

Referring to official letters of the 2nd instant in connection with the erection of new school buildings at Hartley Bay and Bella Coola in your Agency I beg to say that the Department does not consider it advisable to formally call for tenders for either of these buildings owing to the delay that would be unavoidable. The better plan would appear to be for you either to let the contract to some reliable man who will do the work within the sum specified, viz., $1000.00, or else to have it done by day labour, as is proposed at the Bella Coola school. In either case the Department will expect you to see that the workmanship is satisfactory and the building completed in a creditable manner.

Should day labour be adopted the men should be required to work the usual number of hours according to the custom of the locality.

EXTRACT FROM LETTER FROM G. H. BARRY,
DISTRICT INSPECTOR OF INDIAN SCHOOLS,
BRITISH COLUMBIA, dated May 5, 1938.

Desks as recommended in my report are now very badly needed at Hartley Bay. These, I believe, should be provided before the opening of the new school year in September.
Sir,

I beg to report as follows for the month of July

During this trip, the locations of Indian traplines on Gill and Campania Islands were ascertained. We tied up for the night at Surf Inlet, and on the following day proceeded to Hartley Bay which was reached in the evening.

Next morning I went ashore and met Mr. J.A. Findlay, teacher of the day School who, with Mrs. Findlay, is spending the summer vacation at the village. Like other villages we visited, I found nearly all the Indians away at the canneries.

An inspection was made of the school building and some needed repairs were noted. Mr. Findlay asked to have the interior of the school room painted before school opened. While no provision was made for this expenditure in the present estimates, the expense would be so small that I am in favor of having it done. This matter will be taken up separately and the Department informed of the probable cost.

Dear Sir:

Re Your File 168-28-5.

I have to refer to Mr. Hoey's letter of March 21st in which the lumber supplied in the spring of 1938 for the village roadway and the proposed new school at Hartley Bay are dealt with. Perhaps I should add here that instructions were issued to Mr. Collison on December 7th, based on the information and authority contained in your letter of December 1st.

The first lot of lumber supplied was quite unsuitable for the purpose for which it was intended. No doubt it could be used to some extent in connection with the construction of either a new addition to the present school or the proposed new school. The lumber is double dressed fir 1\(\frac{1}{2}\) inch x 6 inch in lengths of 6, 9 and 18 ft.; the quality is not above fair. It probably would in some respects be hard to work lumber of this thickness and width into a new construction, and I am inclined to agree that it could be used to very good advantage in replacing the school sidewalks which now are very much in need of attention.

It undoubtedly would be much better to build a new school at Hartley Bay than add to the present building, which was erected in 1913 and is in need of alteration and repair. I do not consider, however, that definite arrangements for the construction of a new school at this point should be made until a suitable site has been decided upon and handed over to the Department for school purposes. My opinion is that we should have a separate parcel of ground for this school apart entirely from Church property. I should suggest that a school along the lines of the Bella Coola Indian Day School would very well suit the requirements of the Indian children of Hartley Bay.

The Secretary,

NAME OF BUILDING: Hartley Bay Indian Day School

Dear Major MacKay:

As requested I have read Departmental letter 168-28-5 of March 21st with reference to a proposed new school at Hartley Bay, Skeena River Agency.

Mr Hoey is quite correct in his memory of the lumber at Hartley Bay, which was not suitable for the main roadway through the village, but which could be used for an addition to the Indian Day School if the addition was constructed in a rather unusual manner. I regret that I never was able to convey to Mr Indian Agent Collison the plan I had in mind, though Mr Indian Agent Gillett was very certain that we could build an addition with the available lumber. Mr Gillett had been with me at Hartley Bay on our way to Prince Rupert.

The Indians at Hartley Bay are anxious to have a modern school. The present teacher has been a great success. There is no proper place for the elementary Manual Training carried on at this school. The school is overcrowded. For all the above reasons I believe that I might reasonably request that a new school be erected when funds are available. The Indians are members of the United Church and it is under the auspices of that Church that the school is conducted.

To assist you I am suggesting some replies to Mr Hoey's questions:

Name of Building: Hartley Bay Indian Day School.
Location: Hartley Bay near junction of Greenville and Douglas Channels, some 90 miles S.E. of Prince Rupert, B.C.
Recommend Construction: By Indian labour under a "White" foreman. The Indians are intelligent and have erected quite good houses for themselves. They however leave the village for fishing in the summer, June to September inclusive.
Building Requirements: Rooms and Accommodation: Number of Pupils:
Type of Construction: Large classroom to accommodate forty children

The average attendance varies much during the year that during the past three years being tabulated below:

| School Year | 1937-38 | 1938-39 | 1939-40 |
|-------------|---------|---------|---------|
| September Quarter | 27.0    | 15.0    | 12.0    |
| December Quarter   | 28.5    | 26.5    | 25.0    |
| March Quarter      | 28.5    | 27.1    | 32.9    |
| June Quarter       | 20.5    | 27.2    | 19.4    |

It may I think be assumed that the average attendance is some 75% of the total number on the school roll, in the village at the time. Accommodation should therefore be provided for the maximum easily taught by one teacher, up to 40.

Cement basement of sufficient size and height to permit of installation of hot air furnace and small Manual Training room, and leave room for several cords of wood fuel. Manual Training and Domestic Science could be taught in the present building for a time, but if a school is to be erected it would be better to make provision in the new building for the Manual Training and also a small room for Domestic Science. No living accommodation will be needed for the teacher who is United Church Missionary and lives in the Mission House.
Similar type of construction to school lately erected at Pemberton would be very satisfactory.

Description of Site Etc.

School should be located on site taken from Indian Reserve and not on United Church property. Present school is to rear of and to one side of the new United Church building.

Some clearing may have to be undertaken and surface drains placed to carry water away from around basement. Present school is within about 150 yards of sea. Village has only wooden roads and walks. I believe that the rock is very near the surface and that any large excavation is out of the question. The cement basement suggested would have to be constructed as in many of the Provincial Day Schools above the ground level. Outside toilets would be satisfactory as at present.

Water Supply Etc.

I have no information on file. Water is I believe brought in pipes from a short distance to the rear of the village. In any case water would not have to be brought into the proposed school, at least at present.

Toilet Facilities:

Outside toilets with excavated pits.

Heating System Type of Furnace: Fuel.

Hot air furnace with pipes to two outlets in classroom and to other rooms if any provided. Fuel would be wood I believe.

Lighting System:

By gas lamps.

Built-in Equipment Etc.

Two large cupboards with shelves to take sundries and books. Windows should be on one side only leaving all opposite wall and one end for asbestos slate blackboard opposite end for doors and cupboards. Windows should be on left side as children enter doors. Boards should be 4 feet wide and run whole length of side and end mentioned above.

Shipping Instructions for Materials Etc.

Hartley Bay is a port of call of Union Steam Ships from Vancouver. No wharf available. Materials would either have to be landed from Union S. Ship by Indian boats, or better brought from Prince Rupert by scow and towed to beach on high tide.

Remarks:

I consider that the Indian Agent should select a good site for the new school quite apart from any consideration of the present location of old school which was erected by the Department in 1913, and is not in particularly good repair.

I trust that the above information may be of some assistance but suggest that Mr. Indian Agent Collison be asked for more detailed particulars before the plans are drawn. May I suggest that he be supplied with a copy of this letter.

Yours very truly,

Gerald H. Barry

December 6th, 1947

Major D.M. MacKay, Indian Commissioner for B.C., Vancouver, B.C.

RE: Hartley Bay School

On my visit to the school on December 2nd, 1947, there were 12 children present. In November the attendance reached 46 and there are 3 pupils still to come in from the Canneries. There were 3 children attending under seven years of age and the teacher was asked to exclude them. The Council was also notified of the request.

The school is 18 x 24 feet and 10 feet high. It is very old and delapidated. Walls are dark brown and ceilings a dirty buff. Lighting conditions are bad and the children's eyesight is in grave danger. Boards are black hyloplate and badly worn.

The Council have agreed to cut away overgrowth of brush and small trees around the school to improve light. This is to be done free.

It is recommended that during the Xmas vacation the school interior should be painted two coats flat tone, ceilings ivory and walls cream - trim green. Walls are 840 sq. feet and will require 3 gallons cream paint @ $6.90 per gallon. Ceiling is 132 sq. feet and will require 2 gallons paint @ $6.90 per gallon. Trim 2 quarts @ $6.90 (green) per gallon; 6 bottles "Soil Off" for washing prior to painting, 3 brushes @ $2.50. 1 quart of turps will cost $3.00 and 1 quart of green blackboard paint $3.25. Total cost of materials amount to $56.90, which total includes $5.00 for Soil Off. Labour - 6 days for 3 men @ $5.40 per day = $97.20

Total cost of Material - $56.70
Total cost of Labour $27.20
Total cost $153.90.

The work is urgently needed and is recommended for immediate attention. Materials can be bought in Prince Rupert.

Re: Hartley Bay Indian Day School

As the Department is aware, the estimated enrolment at the above mentioned school for the 1949-50 academic year will be over 50 and although the Department is preparing to advertise for the construction of a new school at this point it is obvious that the new building will not be ready until 1950-51 academic year. It is therefore recommended that the items requested by Mr. Superintendent Anfield in his attached letter and requisition be supplied. I have written to Mr. Anfield requesting an estimate of the amount required to put the Council Hall in condition for temporary use. Mr. Inspector Davey is familiar with this building and believes that it can reasonably be prepared for school use on a temporary basis.

W.B. Arneil,
Indian Commissioner for B.C.
The Chief and Council have given the Department the use of the hall on the waterfront as a second classroom. I discussed this with Johnny Clifton today and he expresses on behalf of the Band their satisfaction that the present overcrowding in the school may end this fall. The floor of the hall is in good shape but repairs to the roof will be required and also windows and some work on the end of the hall.

I attach requisitions for primary tables, chairs, blackboards, and teacher's desk and a large oil heater. All this equipment can be moved to the new school when built, so it would appear in order to purchase it at once. In a few days, I shall submit a requisition for needed repairs to the building. I shall send the Naskeena down to Hartley Bay next week to survey the exact needs. I know the hall, however, and am satisfied it can be fixed without undue cost and made to fill a very needed purpose.

Will you please consider that we shall need 2 teachers at Hartley Bay this fall. I will guarantee that the building will be ready for use if the funds are made available.

F. Earl Amfield
Indian Superintendent

Attached please find Voucher No. 847 being charter of a
MV to transport Hartley Bay School equipment from Prince
Rupert to Hartley Bay. This material was put off at Butealld
and arrangements were made with Mr. Malcolm of Canadian Fish,
who very kindly offered to send this equipment gratis to
Hartley Bay. He sent a full load with one of his big packers
only to find at Hartley Bay that a south east gale was blowing
and there being nobody in the village, was impossible to unload
and effect a landing. As you know, there is no wharf or float at
this point. As the boat was urgently required for fishing oper-
ations, the skipper took the load to Rupert where we put it in
storage. The Captain was unable to wait and it has been necessary
to charter a boat to take this load to Hartley Bay.

The job took two days and the cost for the bare expenses
of fuel and oil and the wages of the three men concerned, it
is regretted that this extra expense should be necessary but
there was no other way of getting supplies to Hartley Bay except
by steamer. The first visit of the steamer on the new schedule
will not be until October. It was imperative to get this equip-
ment and this lumber and material to Hartley Bay to get the
new classroom into operation by the time the teachers arrived.

Payment of the account has been rendered for recommendation.

Sgd. F. Earl Anfield,
Indian Superintendent.

Certified to be a true copy of a Minute of a Meeting of the Committee of the Privy Council, approved by His Excellency the Governor General on the 22 September 1948.

The Committee of the Privy Council have had before them a report dated September 14, 1948 from the Minister of Mines and Resources, representing:

That it is immediately necessary, and funds are provided in the 1948-49 estimates, Indian Affairs Branch, Mines and Resources, to provide a two-room Indian day school with attached teachers' residence on the Pemberton Indian Reserve, in the New Westminster Indian Agency, Province of British Columbia;

That it is essential that educational facilities be provided for the Indian children on the Pemberton Indian Reserve;

That Section 36 of The Public Works Act, Chapter 166, R.S.C. 1927, provides in part as follows:

"Whenever any works are to be executed under the direction of any Department of the Government the Minister having charge of such Department shall invite tenders by public advertisement for the execution of such work except in cases (a) of pressing emergency in which delay would be injurious to the public interest...........";

That, due to the very isolated situation of this reserve, there are no builders or contractors in the area nor are outside contractors interested in tenders if invited as aforesaid, as they have all the work they can do in their own localities;

That a competent building company, namely Prefabricated Structures Limited, Post Office Box 459, Vancouver, British Columbia, has offered to undertake the provision of a prefabricated two-room school with attached teachers' residence immediately on a basis of $9,750.00 f.o.b. Vancouver, plus freight and erection supervisor's wages, fare and expenses;

That it is considered that the provision of this school is a pressing emergency and within the exception provided in Section 36 above recited and further, it is considered that the work can be more expeditiously and economically executed as suggested herein.

The Committee, therefore, on the recommendation of the Minister of Mines and Resources, advise that authority be granted to enter into a contract with Prefabricated Structures, Limited, for the provision of this building as outlined above, this being the only arrangement possible at the present time and it being essential that this work be undertaken at once and carried to completion in order that the building will be available for use by the time the Christmas school term commences.

The Honourable A. D. P. Heeney
The Minister of Mines and Resources. Clerk of the Privy Council.

Memorandum:

DEPUTY MINISTER

Hartley Bay, Kincolith and Lakalsap Indian Day Schools.

Included in our Main Estimates for 1949-50 is the sum of $30,000.00 each for the erection of two-room schools and teacherages on each of the above reserves, in the Skeena River Agency, near Prince Rupert, British Columbia.

Whereas our day school building program has met with considerable success in the other provinces, we have encountered many difficulties in British Columbia. At Ucluelet, we advertised for tenders for the erection of a two-room school and attached teachers' residence and the lowest tender for standard construction was $42,612.00. This same school, we are having built in Saskatchewan for $29,000.00. As you are aware, we finally decided to erect a Quonset school at Ucluelet.

At Cape Mudge, we advertised for a one-room school with attached teacher's residence complete with electricity, plumbing, etc. We are having two such schools erected in Ontario for about $17,000.00. The one and only tender received for the erection of the Cape Mudge School was $29,744.75.

At Fort Babine, we advertised for tenders for the erection of a two-room Indian day school and teacherage but received one tender only, in the amount of $67,391.00.

Therefore, due to the scarcity of contractors bidding on our projects and the high prices tendered by them, our officials in British Columbia have come to the decision that prefabricated
schools should be erected on each of the above three reserves. Their decision in this regard has been aided by the satisfaction obtained from the company which erected the two-room school and teacherage at Pemberton Meadows in the New Westminster Agency and the one-room school at Metlakatla in the Skeena River Agency. This company is Prefabricated Structures, Limited, Post Office Box 489, Vancouver, B. C., and I attach both the previous Order-in-Council covering the provision of the Pemberton Meadows School and photographs taken by Inspector Davey of the completed building.

Our officials are perfectly satisfied with these buildings and Mr. Indian Superintendent Anfield, who knows how to supervise the erection of this type of school from his experience at Metlakatla, makes the following statement:

"I am satisfied that it will wear well, operate economically and that the type of construction is suitable and most adaptable for the type of country in the Skeena Agency. The school has been viewed with considerable approval by the Provincial School Inspector, Mr. J. Shell, at Prince Rupert. It is recommended that two-classroom schools of this type, with teacherages attached, be constructed at Hartley Bay, Greenville and Kincolith, with the least possible delay."

With regard to advertising for tenders, not only have we our previous disappointments as a guide, but Mr. Anfield makes the following statement:

"I have approached Messrs. Mitchell and Currie, Greer and Bridden, both contracting firms of Prince Rupert and they refuse to bid on the construction of new schools at these three points, giving isolation of location and risk re transportation as the main reasons. These and other contractors in Prince Rupert have so much other work on hand that they are just not interested."

Mr. Indian Commissioner Arnell concurs in these recommendations and points out that these buildings can be erected at a cost to the Department considerably less than we could get a quotation from a contractor. In this regard he makes the following statement:
"You will note Mr. Anfield's reference to the need for employment at these Indian villages. Erection of these schools will provide some of that much-needed employment and in addition will ensure most urgently required classroom accommodation and, as previously pointed out, at a saving of several thousand dollars in each case."

The only other company in British Columbia producing schools of this type is Precision Housing Company, which produces pre-cut schools. These are much more difficult to erect with the type of semi-skilled Indian labour we will have available and are not recommended by our field officials.

Therefore, I have no hesitation in recommending to you for presentation to the Minister, the attached Submission to Council covering the purchase of three prefabricated schools from Prefabricated Structures, Limited, Post Office Box 489, Vancouver, B.C., for erection on these three reserves in the Skeena River Agency. We have foremen-carpenters in mind and can employ the Indians who are fairly competent mechanics and carpenters, under white supervision, for the erection of these prefabricated buildings.

Director.

Specifications for One & Two Room Schools

With Attached Teacherage

1. GENERAL - Good grade Pacific Coast Fir, Hemlock or Cedar especially selected for the purpose for which it is to be used. All material is accurately machined and code marked for identification. Fully illustrated erection procedure, blueprints and checking lists are provided.

2. FOUNDATION - These buildings are designed for a full basement. 2 x 6 x 8 beams are supplied with 6 x 6 and 6 x 6 posts; this gives a joist span of 8' centre to centre. Concrete is not supplied. Materials for forms (shiplap and 2 x 4) can be supplied at extra cost.

3. BASEMENT - Basement walls, doors, stairs, beams and posts are supplied.

4. FLOOR - 2 x 10 floor joists are supplied to be placed 16" on centre. 2 x 10 box sill and bridging are supplied. Shiplap subfloor is supplied in random lengths to be laid diagonally. 2 x 6 joists 16" on centre are supplied for teacherage.

5. WALLS - Walls consist of multi-flex sections. These sections are 4 x 10 and 6 x 10 for the school building and 2 x 6 to 12 x 6 for the teacherage. Each section is faced with tongue and groove centre match lumber with building paper between studs and sheathing. Between each section a 4 x 4 pilaster is placed. These pilasters are grooved to receive tongues on outer stud of wall section. Top and bottom plates are dadoed to receive pilasters. This method of construction ensures a tight and well constructed wall. Windows are fitted in frames complete with sash balances and hardware. Outside doors are hung in frames and equipped with locks.

6. ROOF - Roof is of trussed construction with 2 x 6 ceiling joists and 2 x 4 rafters placed 16" on centre making a self supporting roof independent of partitions. Roof boards are cut to length. Wood gutter and V joint soffit are supplied in random lengths. Cedar or 16/12 Burwood type shingles are supplied (heavier patent shingles can be supplied at extra cost).

7. INTERIOR - All studding is supplied cut to length. Partition plates are supplied random. Interior door frames are machined ready for assembly. Ten/Twelve wallboard is supplied throughout with sufficient 1/8" masonite or ½" P.V. hardboard for 4" high in classrooms and halls. Inside casing cut to length and mitred. Base and floor mould are supplied. Finish floor is 1 x 4 V.G. Fir throughout except kitchen and bathroom in teacherage which is flat grain.

8. CABINETS - Kitchen cabinets, ironing board and medicine cabinet are supplied for teacherage.

9. EXTERIOR - Choice of ½ x 8 clear cedar bevel siding, ¾ x 8 or ¾ x 10 Common cedar bungalow siding, 1 ¼ x 10 Holly Varden pattern Common cedar siding or Capilano Cedarwall shingles for exterior walls at quoted price.

10. HARDWARE - All necessary locksets, hinges, sash fasteners and sash balances are supplied. Also all nails necessary for erection. Flashing for chimney is included.

11. INSULATION AND PAPER - 2" Rockwool batts or equivalent insulation is supplied, also building paper for floors and outer walls.

12. BLACKBOARD - Material for blackboards with necessary mouldings are supplied.

13. Front and rear steps as shown on blueprint are included.

NOT SUPPLIED: Concrete, brick work, plumbing, electrical or heating equipment or paint.

Indian Affairs Branch,
Dept. of Mines and Resources,
Ottawa, Ont.

Re: School Construction - Skeena River Agency

With reference to Colonel Neary's army signal's message of January 16th, I am forwarding Superintendent Anfield's letter of January 21st, wherein he reports with regard to the foremen employed on the three school construction projects in his agency and also details the progress made on each project.

We have experienced most extreme winter weather conditions in British Columbia during the past month and as construction could only be carried on at an exorbitant cost, it is felt that Mr. Anfield was wise in laying off the foremen temporarily.

We had originally intended to ship the first building to Greenville but the Nass River froze three days before the building arrived and consequently it was diverted to Kincolith and the building intended for Kincolith was shipped to Hartley Bay. The third building is ready for shipment from Vancouver.

There is some doubt as to whether or not we will be able to get to Greenville before the end of the fiscal year. You will be advised when work on these projects is resumed.

(sgd) W.S. Arneil
Indian Commissioner for B.C.

January 26, 1950.

With reference to your circular of January 24th requesting vouchering on Purchase Order No. 51233, Hartley Bay Indian Day School.

Please be advised that due to impossible weather, Prefabricated Structures Ltd., have been advised to hold delivery of this order until better weather makes it possible for us to take it into the site.

It should be explained to the Department, however, that due to icing conditions in the Nass River, the first of the three schools shipped and scheduled for Greenville (lakal-sap) was put off at Kincolith where it will be erected. The second school shipped would have gone into Greenville had river conditions ameliorated. They became worse and this school was moved to Hartley Bay.

This information is given to the Department with reference to my statement in a progress report to Commissioner Arneil, that school buildings were at Kincolith and Hartley Bay.

Estimate for Wiring School and Teacherage, Hartley Bay, B.C.

Our estimate of $963.80 covers the following:

Wiring of the school and Teacherage as per specifications, the basement being wired in 1/2" rigid conduit, using No. 14 wire, and the provision and installation of Loxon wire guards around the basement fixtures with the exception of the furnace room.

Provision and installation of all service equipment, including 10 circuit distribution panel and 60 amp circuit breaker in the school and a 60 amp cut off in the power house. Wiring between school and power house to be No. 6 Weatherproof wire.

Wiring of the classrooms and teacherage in 2/14 loomex non-metallic sheathed cable.

Provide and install Warden V-717 semi indirect ceiling fixtures for the classrooms. All wiring to be in accordance with the B.C. Electrical Code, and all materials and fixtures C.E.S.A. approved.

An additional $50.00 to be charged for the installation and hook-up of the 5kw plant provided by the department. Board and room for electricians to be provided by the department, plus $2.00 per hour per man while travelling to and from the site.

Having already complete roughing-in of the wiring at Kincolith, and thus obtaining a more accurate estimate of our costs of labour and material, we find it necessary to increase our estimate for these schools.

Yours very truly,

Rupert Radio & Electric

For your information and in accordance with your

as roughing in of Hartley Bay in particular must be in hand within

Memorandum:

DEPUTY MINISTER

Re: Plumbing and Heating -

Hartley Bay Indian Day School,
Kincolith Indian Day School,
Lakalap Indian Day School,

in the Skeena River Agency.

Mr. Indian Commissioner Ameil has forwarded two tenders for the installation of plumbing and heating in these two-room day schools. These two tenders have been received from the following firms:

1. Smith and Elkins Limited, P.O. Box 274, Prince Rupert, B.C.
2. Baanich Plumbing and Heating Ltd., Box 1158, Prince Rupert, B.C.

Smith and Elkins' bid is for $1,090.00 per school. It is presumed that the piping would be standard water piping or galvanized. It is also noted that the bid on the supplying of a well pump with motor and tank has been made but it does not indicate if this bid includes the installation.

The bid from the Baanich Plumbing and Heating works out at $1,092.63 per school which is only $2.63 more than the bid of Smith and Elkins. It is definitely preferable to employ this firm because their tender includes copper piping and joints. It is also noted that this firm will supply pressure tanks and pumps and will install these.
Our Indian Superintendent at Prince Rupert has, therefore, recommended the acceptance of the Saanich Plumbing and Heating tender. Mr. Indian Commissioner Arnell and one of his engineers have also reviewed these tenders and have concurred in the recommendation of the acceptance of the bid from this company.

I would, therefore, recommend to you the acceptance of the tender from the Saanich Plumbing and Heating Limited, of Prince Rupert, B.C., in the amount of $3,277.50 for the installation of plumbing and heating facilities in these three Indian Day Schools.

Director.

[Signature]

Recommended

Acting Deputy Minister.

Approved:

Minister.

[Signature]
Ottawa, April 4, 1950.

Memorandum:

DEPUTY MINISTER

Electricity Installations in Indian Day Schools in the Skeena River Agency

As you are aware, we are erecting three prefabricated schools at Kincolith, Hartley Bay and Lakalsap. Originally we had hoped to complete these projects by the end of the fiscal year but unusually severe weather has prevented this.

The buildings are now ready for wiring and Mr. Arneil has called for tenders for this work. An army message was received from him reading as follows:

"Tenders for wiring Kincolith, Hartley Bay and Greenville schools have been secured and reviewed by our engineering staff. Rupert Radio & Electric submitted lowest tender $843.60 per school covering wiring to electrical code based on our engineers plan if company's tender can be accepted immediately wiring to Kincolith can be completed before March 31".

In view of the information contained in Mr. Arneil's army message, I would recommend to you the acceptance of the lowest tender received from Rupert Radio and Electric, in the amount of $843.60 per school. Arrangements can be made for this work to be completed in early April.

Director.

Recommended:

Deputy Minister

Approved:

Minister.

Attached please find bid from Rupert Radio & Electric, on the electrical work proposed to be undertaken at the Hartley Bay Indian Day School this Agency.

It is noted that this firm, which is doing the Kincolith job, has raised their price. I contacted the Manager and asked him why. For your information and in accordance with your Army Signal of April 16, we wrote to the Northern B.C. Power Co. and they have this morning informed me through the manager, Mr. T. B. Black, that they are not going to bid on the work as they cannot take out of town jobs.

The Parkin Electric Co. referred to in your Army Signal is out of business.

Rupert Radio & Electric have done a dandy job at Kincolith and if the bid is still low, it is recommended that they be given the contract for the two remaining schools without delay as roughing in of Hartley Bay in particular must be in hand within 10 days.

Re: Demolition of Old School Buildings, Hartley Bay, Greenville and Kincolith.

In reply to Superintendent Anfield's letter of May 5th, attached, he was requested to investigate the possibility of having Indians of the Bands concerned demolish the above-mentioned buildings on a free labour basis, in return for any materials they might salvage.

You will note from his letter of May 26th, attached, that he has been successful in making such an arrangement at Hartley Bay, but that at Kincolith and Greenville, it will cost a total of $1,000.00 to demolish the buildings and improve the sites. These old buildings are a fire hazard to the new school buildings, in addition to which, the space they occupy is required. There would appear to be no alternative but to recommend approval of the expenditure necessary. I doubt whether Mr. Anfield included the cost of demolishing these old buildings in his estimate of the costs of these new schools, and if necessary, would recommend transfer of $1,000.00 of the Appropriation for the Joint School, Port Essington, to meet the cost of the work.

W. S. Arneil,
Indian Commissioner for B. C.
Demolition Old School Buildings

Further to yours of May 22, 1950 re above noted subject; conversations have taken place with the Councils and I am able to advise as follows: (1) Hartley Bay: the council agree to take possession of and remove the old School Building and rebuild it as a Council Hall. As no fire risk is involved at Hartley Bay, this is recommended and action will be taken to draw an agreement with the Council to this end. The site of the present school is required for a playground. (2) Kincolith: this is the real hazard as when the outbuildings are completed, the new school will be only six inches away from the old premises. It is recommended that $600.00 be made available immediately to demolish this building; to pile usable material and burn the rest, leaving the site clean. Men are away fishing now; it is imperative this building be taken down whilst our crew and tractor are available. (3) Greenville: there is a fire hazard here, though not so great as Kincolith, as the old building will be 20 feet away from the new. The men are away for the summer; it is recommended the building be torn down and everything burned down that is not salvageable. The good material to be piled off in a safe area for future disposition. Cost estimated at $400.00.

In the original estimate we had planned to remove all nails (which are dynamite in a furnace) and cut all waste into usable lengths for fuel. This will not be done. It was not possible to do this before, as all buildings are in use.

Your instructions are requested.

F. Earl Anfield,
Indian Superintendent.

Re: Demolition of old buildings,
Hartley Bay, Greenville, Kincolith

I have discussed with Inspector R.F. Davey, the need
of immediate demolition of the old school buildings at the
above-noted villages, where new construction is presently in
hand.

At Kincolith, the old school is less than four feet
from the new building. The old structure is at least 50 years
old and totally unfit for further use as a structure. It will
be and is a gross fire risk and must be removed.

At Greenville, the new building will be approximately
20 feet from the new structure. It is 52 years old and is of no
further value as a structure.

At Hartley Bay, the old school is a fairly safe
distance from the new school but is close to the church and
Mission House and when unused, would be a fire hazard to village
structures.

It is planned to demolish these three buildings and to
salvage any usable timber and joists for playground equipment and
perhaps secure enough V-joint or siding for fencing around the
new school.

The balance of the material will be cut up for kindling
and fuel for the new school buildings.

A careful check on costs has been made and the
demolition, clearing up and levelling of sites, will cost as
follows:

Memorandum:

DEPUTY MINISTER

Re: Hartley Bay Indian Day School,
Kincolith Indian Day School,
Lekalsap Indian Day School,
Skeena River Indian Agency, B.C.,
Electoral District of Skeena.

Construction of the above buildings has proceeded to the point where it is essential that arrangements be made immediately for heating installations.

Indian Superintendent F.E. Anfield has obtained the following tenders for the installation of heating systems in the above three schools.

1. Shenton's Sheet Metal Works, Prince Rupert, B.C. $4,350.00
2. G.H. Tomlinson, Prince Rupert, B.C. $5,970.00
3. Thom Sheet Metal Ltd., Prince Rupert, B.C. $6,564.76

Mr. Robinson, the engineer attached to the office of the Indian Commissioner for British Columbia, has reviewed the tenders and considers that the lowest one will meet the requirements of the three schools mentioned above. Indian Commissioner Arnell recommends acceptance of the tender of Shenton's Sheet Metal Works in an amount of $4,350.00 and I would appreciate it if the Minister would approve.

Recommended Director.

We have noted your recommendation with reference to the demolition of the old schools. We are extremely reluctant to authorize any expenditure for the tearing down of old buildings as in most cases we have had individual Indians or groups of Indians demolish the schools and use the lumber for the erection of their own homes. These buildings were given free to the Indians on the understanding that all lumber, etc., would be removed. The only expenditure needed is the sum for the filling in of the old foundation.

Therefore, would you please refer this matter again to Mr. Anfield in the hope that a similar arrangement can be made at Kincith and Lakalsap.

Departmental approval is given for the Indian Council removing the old school building at Hartley Bay and using it as a Council hall. It is understood that there will be no expense in this connection as far as the Department is concerned.

The Treasury Branch is unable to decide in what manner the firm is charging for the storage. Is it by weight, board measure or the length of time the goods were stored? They also raise the question of why the Voucher was not issued in favour of Prefabricated Structures, as the account attached to the Voucher is addressed to that firm and not to the Department.

You are aware, of course, that our Treasury holds the Power of Attorney which provides that all payments due Prefabricated Structures should be made to the firm mentioned on Power of Attorney.

In this connection, I direct your attention to Voucher 95 from the Skeena River Agency dated January 5th, 1950. This Voucher also covered freight charges and was approved by you. Payment was requested and was made to Prefabricated Structures.

A complete explanation regarding this Voucher will be necessary before it can be paid.

PUBLIC ARCHIVES ARCHIVES PUBLIQUES CANADA
Further to my Army Signal of today's date, attached herewith please find a statement showing the financial position of the School Construction project in this Agency as at August 12th, 1950. In spite of my best hopes, it is now found that a further appropriation of $8,138.08 will be required to complete these jobs, including the installation of lighting plants, storm doors and windows, and the conveying of school furnishings and equipment, including desks, to these schools.

The last crew came out from Kincolith last weekend, and as most of these men are moving to Ocean Falls immediately, where they will be employed, it was essential that they be paid off and that income tax deductions and unemployment insurance books be all paid up and stamped. It is to be noted that a further appropriation of $4,006.29 for Hartley Bay is included in the total amount requested, as is also a sum of $5,631.31 for Kincolith. Against these two sums there is a credit of $1,499.52 in the appropriation for Greenville. This makes a net amount of $8,138.08 required by further appropriation for Vote 516.

An accountable advance in the sum of $8,657.98 (included in the total required) is requested before the end of this month to meet the following payments:

Hartley Bay: 813

Deficit on wage account ........................................... $306.44
Rental of equipment from Indians .................................. 150.00
Wages and boat hire for freight and hauling balance of equipment required and, installing desks, windows and lighting plant ............................................. 500.00

Total .................. $956.44

These items do not include wages for wiring in the plant or for freighting on same from Vancouver, to Prince Rupert.
Greenville:827

Deficit on wage account ........................................ $2,314.46
Rental on tractor and truck and boats from Indians outstanding .............. 450.00
Wages for freight and hauling balance of equipment and installing in the schools: ............. 500.00

Total: .......... 3,264.46

Kincolith: 817

Deficit on wage account ........................................ 3,581.08
Rental of trucks and equipment from Indians ............ 350.00
Wages for freight and boat hire, hauling and installing lighting plants, desks, windows, and furniture to school ......................... 500.00

Total: .......... 4,431.08

We are now preparing a cost analysis of these projects, by schools under different subheads, and as soon as completed they will be forwarded to the Department. This analysis will include inventories of all equipment returned from these projects and will set up credit for them against each school. When these statements are completed, we shall then have a fairly exact picture and detailed cost analysis on these three schools.

F. Earl Anfield,
Indian Superintendent.

Dear Sir,

According to printed rules I have in my possession I understand that the summer holidays for Ind. Day Schools begin July 1st and that no change is to be made without the express approval of the Dept. For the summer of 1914 I obtained permission to keep open for two weeks in July; but unfortunately the School was not benefited.
as the fish were running early that year, and the children went off to their fish camps.

Last year 1915 I did not write for permission to prolong the school session, and it so happened that the last day of June I closed with seventeen children, and opened in September with five. Needless to say I regretted not having obtained permission to keep open part of July. This year I am asking the Dept. that I may use my own judgment as to the advisability of closing at the end of June or a week or two later.

September month has generally a low average owing to the children still being in the woods and mountains gathering berries.

Sir,

I have the honour to acquaint herewith the Department that of the Teachers of the Indian day schools, belonging to this district, that of the Hazelton school - Miss E.J. Seal - is preeminent for proficiency and applicability of imparting it, and the results derived are most excellent in comparison.

Therefore, I would respectfully recommend that her salary be increased to the amount of $600.00 per annum.

This Teacher, aside of being highly qualified, applies the whole of her time, on a very intelligent and consistent basis, solely to the progress of that school. In connection therewith she has the happy faculty of ingratiating herself with the pupils' parents by visiting their homes, in order, to obtain and preserve a good attendance where the distractions from school, as here at Hazelton, are constant and so varied.

By an unfailing tact and effectiveness Miss Seal contrives to have the clearest of class rooms, preserves perfect discipline, and has moulded the pupils of this school in manners and deportment, and general good behaviour, reaching as well beyond its confines. I here, moreover, beg to add that Miss Seal, as a diligent and continuous worker, has taught school for four years at Metlakatla, and took up her present work since the 1st of September 1905; and upon conclusive judgment will remain with it.

Purely in recognition of the merits this case deserves, am I impelled to recommend the Department's favourable consideration coupled with the fact that here, under existing conditions, a lady's expenses for subsistence are extremely high.

I have the honour to be,

Sir,

Sir,

Absence from the mainland at Massett, B.C.I., has delayed my answering your letters of Feb 13 and 19, No 67,340-1, and 125,342-1 which awaited my return.

I take these letters as asking for my candid opinion upon what we all feel to be a most difficult problem. Let me say first that I am most anxious to assist the Department in every possible way in carrying out their new policy of improved Day Schools. I have thought the matter over long and carefully and discussed it with some of our missionaries. I am quite willing to sacrifice denominational pride for the best interests of the Indians. Allow me to express my views freely in hope of helping the cause.

1. No one policy will suit all parts of Canada. It is necessary to modify a general policy according to local conditions. The policy of an improved day school as outlined by the Department seems to suggest the Prairies rather than British Columbia.

2. Speaking for the Church of England in Northern British Columbia let me try and explain the local conditions.

We began Christian work among the Coast Indians over fifty years ago. Our 2,300 Christianized Indians have their homes in villages, most of them live in modern houses, dress well &c. In almost every village there is a clergyman and his wife and family. The clergyman is practically a doctor.

Without
Without any remuneration he is constantly tending the sick, gives practical advice, tells them the danger of evil germs, urges them to keep their houses clean, his wife (like Mrs. Collison of Kincolith) is constantly giving the women hints in domestic matters, there is a day school in the village, usually taught by a white woman, a single lady who lives with the missionary and his wife. It would be impossible for a single lady to live elsewhere in the village. The cost of reaching these villages up the rivers is considerable. The freight on food &c. is excessive, and yet the Department only allows $500.00 a year, subject to reduction, to keep up this Day School, pay travelling expenses and teacher's salary. I have inspected the Day Schools at Metlatac, Kitkatla, Massett, Kincolith, Lakkal-zag, Aiyansh, Gitwangak, Hazelton &c., and found, not as I have found east of the Rockies, three or four children in a school, but from fifteen to forty-five. The younger generation of our Indians have all passed through these Day Schools and the result is far beyond what the Department could possible expect from such inadequate support. I have heard a young Indian man read the lessons in Church in English better than many white men could and yet he had had no other education than that obtained at the village day school. Viewed in the light of relative expenditure I have no hesitation in saying that there has been far greater returns from the Day School than the so-called Industrial School which on the per capita system could not afford to keep first class trades instructors. It is on this ground that I appeal to the Department to use some of the money saved from the closing of our Metlatac Industrial School and strengthen these Day Schools which under great disadvantages have accomplished so much good.

It seems
It seems invidious for me to name two of these Day Schools and leave the others out. I mentioned Massett because it is the largest Day School, so on the roll, and the place is 60 miles from the mainland, and Aiyansh because a school midway between Aiyansh and Gitlakdamiks would answer both villages and give a good number of children but all these Day Schools should be considered and an increased grant made.

Accepting the policy of the improved Day School and applying it to our local conditions here what are the modifications necessary?

From the description given of our villages it will be seen that a nurse is scarcely needed. Some one should have authority to inspect the Indian houses and order a thorough disinfecting once or twice a year.

Except in the case of a school midway between Aiyansh and Gitlakdamiks a mid-day meal does not seem necessary. Many of our Indians are adopting our food. They all have kitchen stoves. They know how to cook. They are not in want. It is mistaken policy for the Government to relieve the parents of the duty of providing for their children.

In regard to industrial training, very few of the children attending day school are old enough to profit from a course of industrial training.

The very best thing the Government could do for our Indians is to employ a first class carpenter and boat-builder and have him visit our villages in turn forming classes of young men from 16 up. Most of our Indians are very quick with tools, the Massett men build fine schooners. A skilled white man could teach them much that would be most useful in a short course. It would not be necessary to visit each village.
village each year.

Let me now mention the one great difficulty in the way of making the Day School meet the need of the ordinary Indian child. Absence from home at certain seasons. If our Indians lived all the year round in their villages there would be no need whatever for Boarding Schools or Industrial Schools except one central undemocratical one for a few of the most promising and perfectly sound children, but this is not the case. The cannery season from June 15 to Sept. 1st. does not seriously interfere as most of this is vacation time, but in most of our villages there is another season which comes in March or April when the parents go off and take their children. They would gladly leave them behind them if we could in any way house and feed them for a few weeks. I have thought much over this and talked it over with our leading missionaries. They all agree that this is the problem.

Meet this difficulty and the Day School is all that the ordinary child needs, and the parents will not feel the separation as in the case of a distant Boarding School. "My child might as well be dead" said one mother bitterly when she found she could not get her child back for eight years.

In some cases only a few of the people go away at one time. If we had a man and his wife in charge, a tent that would hold a dozen children, with blankets &c might meet the need. I think the parents would be willing to provide food for their children during their absence. Our Missionaries are willing to co-operate as they see the importance of keeping the children at school. The difficulty is that an equipment is needed for a short time.

To come to details. Nasset has 50 children on the roll.

If anything...
If anything in the way of an improved Day School is attempted, this school should stand first. If the Department takes up the proposal to have a joint school midway between Aiyansh and Gitladamiks, giving a midday meal I understand that the Aiyansh people will give 1 and 1/2 acres, and Gitladamiks the same on the boundary. There is a good road winter and summer. Distance from each village about one mile. As the Department has promised new school houses there should be economy in combining buildings, salaries etc.

As to Hazelton we have a splendid teacher there, Miss Scal, who also is a deaconess and visits the native people in their homes. I have heard that the Methodists are pressing for a Boarding School there. The Church of England has in Hazelton and neighbourhood about 600 Indians, the Methodists none in Hazelton but in the vicinity (10 miles north and 10 miles south) about 270, the Salvation Army a few dozen, the Roman Catholics have a village 3 or 4 miles away.

Plainly the only way to have a successful Boarding School is for us all to unite upon an inter-denominational school with the privilege of giving religious instruction to our own flock. So far as our Indians in Hazelton are concerned an improved day school on the line indicated would, I think, meet the need. Why should the Government take children away from their parents and clothe and feed them when these parents live in good houses, earn good wages etc.?

As I have already pointed out travelling expenses are high, the cost of living much greater than in the East, it is necessary to offer a man and his wife a good salary to make
to make it worth their while to go to an out of the way place and live among Indians. I earnestly trust that the Department will recognize the fact that the Day Schools cannot be made efficient on $300.00 a year. Until I know how much the salary is to be I cannot very well secure capable teachers but I shall be looking out for such.

Yours faithfully,

F.H. DuVernet,
Bishop of Caledonia.

Dear Sir,

At our Diocesan Synod held last week, it was decided to send one of our experienced lady missionaries to Hazelton to assist the Rev. J. Field relieving him of the Indian School work.

It is now twenty-five years ago since the Church of England began work among the Indians of Hazelton. The Rev. J. Field has been labouring there for nineteen years, teaching the Indian Day School etc., for some years he drew the Indian Department's grant for the day school but through excessive conscientiousness he has taught the Indian Day School for the last four or five years without asking for the grant Government grant. The Church of England has erected a fine new building for this work and the average attendance of scholars has been very fair. Now that we have decided to strengthen the school work at Hazelton we appeal to the Indian Department through you for a renewal of the Government grant. Our conference also decided to send a qualified teacher to Yishgegas, a Church of England Mission sixty miles above Hazelton where we have kept an Indian Day School for some years past, unaided by the Government except the year Dr. Ardagh taught the school there. We appeal for a day school grant for this important station on the Babine river.

We notice in the public press that there is a talk of establishing an Industrial School at Hazelton under Methodist auspices. We would most respectfully point out to the Department that Hazelton has been for 25 years a Church of England Mission and that according to the Government Census of 1904...
of 1904 there are over six hundred Church of England Indians on the Upper Skeena River 3½ miles above the Canyon, and two hundred and seventy-three Methodist Indians in the same District and if the Indian Department contemplates establishing an Industrial School at Hazelton we trust that the Church of England may be accorded the privilege of securing teachers—farm instructor, &c.,

As there is no mail up the Skeena river at present I am sending this letter direct to you as Superintendent writing another with a copy of this enclosed to Mr. R.E. Loring the Indian Agent at Hazelton. The Diocese of Caledonia covers the Northern half of British Columbia.

I remain,

Yours faithfully,

Du

Dear Sir,

I write to ask your kind permission for closing the Hazelton School for the month of May. The children during that month are gardening, and the average for that month is the lowest of the year.

My reason for asking this favour is as follows. The clergyman in whose house I have been living since I
came to Hazelton in 1905 is obliged on health grounds to go South for a time. It is expedient that someone should go with him, his wife for various reasons is unable to do so, his son is in the Army. They have no other relations, therefore it seems to me, I should help them in this their time of need. I will do my best to fill in the time thus given, keeping open Easter week and two weeks in July.

Hoping sincerely that the Dept will kindly consent to this unusual request.

Yours truly,

E. J. Soal

Dear Sir,

I regret to say that after fourteen years as Teacher of the Hazelton Ind. Day School I am sending in my resignation to take place the end of March, as I am then getting married. Since Capt. Mortimer has been Indian Agent the schools have been much more interesting, and during this last twelve months the attendance has more than doubled; which of course means more work. The average attendance is 38-40 at the same time the parents are most interested and anxious that their children are well educated.

If you remember one of my pupils (Joseph Smith) won a Bronze Medal for an Essay on the History of Confederation. I mention this and the general progress of all the pupils to show that I have faithfully carried out my duties as teacher. Capt. Mortimer has often said that my
school is one of the best; but when the question of raising my salary was mentioned his Scotch instinct came to the rescue.

In this North Country the cost of living is very high. Printing my application will be considered.

I am

Your obedient servant
Eva Wingate

Dear Sir:

In reply to your letter dated the 11th November last, having reference to Mr. Inspector Cairns's report on his inspection of the Hazelton Indian Day School last Oct., regarding irregular attendance of the pupils.

I beg to inform you that I have had this school under personal observation for the past two months and I am glad to report that the attendance shows marked improvement. I have instructed the Dominion Constable to pay regular visits to the school and to warn the parents of defaulting children.

It has come to my knowledge that it has been rumored among the Indians here, that a residential school for the Indians will be built on the Hazelton Indian Reserve next year. I mentioned the matter to Mrs. Dungate, the teacher, who informed me that the Rev. Mr. T. Proctor, the Anglican preacher at Hazelton, had told her such a school was going to be built across the Skeena River on the west portion of the Hazelton Indian Reserve. I am of the same opinion as Mrs. Dungate that such unfounded rumors have made the parents think that by not sending their children to the Indian Day School a Residential School would be provided.

Your obedient Servant,

Indian Agent.

Sir:

I beg to inform you that the Department has approved of the appointment of Miss Lillian Shore as teacher of the Hazelton Indian day school, from the first of the present year, at a salary of $75 per month for the ten teaching months in the year, supplemented by any bonus provided by law.

In a few cases where teachers had to travel to remote points, we allowed transportation expenses. Name of Teacher: Mr. Noel Stewart Age 26.

This teacher is a very active young man. He has very little idea of actual teaching technique. He tells me that although he has had five years experience and regular inspection, he has never been told what to do and where he is failing. He seemed to be very glad to have my advice and critical evaluation of his work, and he promised me that he would change his somewhat harsh methods at once. He was advised to attend the Provincial Summer School in Victoria this year and to qualify in Primary Work of which he is rather ignorant at present. He may turn out a good teacher LATER.

Attendance problem: remedies suggested, etc.

The children are not attending well owing to the fact that the teacher straps far too much, and fails to visit the parents when children are away. He has relied on the R.C.M.P. and ruined the tone of the school so well built up by the previous teacher. I have instructed the present teacher to visit the parents of all his pupils and not only those who may happen to be Anglicans.

I am not satisfied with the progress being made by the children here. Many are dirty and poorly dressed.

The Indian Agent has been very ill and not able to exercise a constant supervision of this school during the past year or I am certain he would not have permitted the present state of things to continue.

I consider that the fault lies with the Anglican authority, the Right Rev. Bishop Rix, in nominating Missionary teachers without B.C. qualifications, who are in fact quite unable to teach the school, whatever they may or may not be able to do as Missionaries.

As Mr. Frank Burling's appointment was temporary in the first place so that we could see how well he got on here, I would recommend strongly that the Department arrange with Bishop Rix for a properly qualified teacher to be placed here as from September 1939 at latest.

Extract from Inspector Barry's report on the Hazelton Indian Day School dated October 16, 1938.

As you will see from my report I do not consider that Mr. Burling is a success here. He does not have the respect of the Indian parents who consider, the Indian Agent states, that their children are just wasting their time in school. They give this as a reason for not sending the children regularly.

As Mr. Burling only holds a temporary appointment and does not have a B.C. teacher's certificate, I see no reason why I should recommend that he be retained here.

We require a well qualified B.C. teacher with experience. The practice of appointing the local Missionary of the Anglican Church is a poor one, though I have little hope that the Department will wish to change this till the two room Indian day school which I have recommended is erected.

I do consider that the Right Reverend Bishop Rix should be asked to nominate a properly qualified B.C. trained teacher to succeed Mr. Burling at the end of the present academic year, if not sooner.

I am very sorry that I have to report in this unsatisfactory way on Mr. Burling's work. In my last report on this school, very soon after his appointment, I expressed the hope that with an experienced teacher the children would make rapid progress. It is however my duty to point out that the present condition of the Hazelton Indian day school is highly unsatisfactory. The Indian Agent is, I believe, well aware of this, though, owing to his illness, he has only been able to visit the school once since my last inspection.

The greatest surprise in my life came from the reports of Dr. Barry. His adverse reports generally deal with those whom I have every reason to believe are among the very best of our teachers of natives. Certainly I would have looked far afield before I could have obtained one so well qualified for the position as Mr. Burling of Hazelton. He is a gentleman in every respect, by both breeding and education, a qualified teacher with a successful career behind him. Mr. Barry has, perhaps of necessity, the habit of visiting the schools in this area just after they get started in the Fall and before nearly all the natives have returned from their fishing. Consequently he often finds the attendance small, and the children not yet settled down to work.

As to attendance, the actual figure for the average attendance for the fall term of 1937 was 33.86 and in 1938 it was 35.78. A few children having reached the age of sixteen years or over, were taken out of school as they were needed at home, and one school girl of 17 was married. My dear Mr. Hoey:

After I received your last letter re the Hazelton School I determined I would say no more about it. But recently there are developments there which urge me to again write you.

When the natives heard that there was the probability of Mr. Burling being removed, they were up in arms and held indignation meetings. They had two meetings, at the second of which they passed unanimously resolutions declaring their entire satisfaction with Mr. Burling as a teacher and citizen.

I got to know of this through the Editor of a Prince Rupert paper to whom they had sent a long communication signed by the Chief native of Hazelton. It contained a great deal of adverse criticism of the Indian Agent, going back over several years, which I advised the Editor not to publish as it was extremely personal and most of it out of date. However, he did publish the enclosed, which will show you that some of the things of which you were informed were not accurate. When you read this I hope you will reconsider the dismissal of Mr. Burling, of whom I can confidently say he is an outstanding teacher and an altogether good man.

Dear Sir:

After much deliberation I have decided to write in protest against the reports of Inspector Barry & Mr. Mortimer, the Indian Agent, on my work and influence among the natives of Hazelton.

In the two previous terms, school work was seriously hampered by epidemics—diphtheria, measles, whooping cough. The last continued all August also among white children in town.

When the Inspector visited, many of those present had only just returned after three months absence; coupled with the broken attendance of preceding terms, the backwardness of pupils was not to be wondered at.

My methods of teaching over a long period of years have invariably met with success. Twice returning to Canada after the war I have had charge of schools ranging from rural (one-roomed), to town high schools. I have taught various nationalities & amongst the non-English, my methods have increased the attendance three-fold.

When here, the Inspector took the beginners' class in reading,
but only succeeded in frightening them into speechlessness.

He then resorted to calling older brothers or sisters from other classes to stand with them. Were I to adopt such methods, the work of the school would be disorganized.

I object strongly to the sarcastic asides in which he indulges; such tactics are subversive to school discipline. Other teachers have spoken to me on this matter.

Shortly after his visit an outside teacher called. He complimented me on the appearance of the school, and the quality of pupils' work shown round the walls. I do not give his name for obvious reasons.

Inspector Barry said he had not seen the Agent, but during the afternoon he charged me with excluding pupils of fifteen years. This I strongly repudiated, & asked the name of his informant. It was the Agent. He also hinted that the Agent & I were not on good terms. This was astounding to me, as I have not had more than three conversations with the Agent since my arrival in Sept. 57.

From the registers of past years it appears that this school has had frequent changes of teachers; surely something must be wrong when there is no continuity of tenure; it is certain that no school can make progress under such conditions.

Regarding the Agent's report, I can state most emphatically that his criticism is entirely erroneous. The attitude of the natives is most friendly & the Native Brotherhood is solid on my behalf. It is the Agent who has not the respect of the natives.

Please pardon this somewhat lengthy letter but I feel sure you will allow me to state my case.

Believe me,

Yours faithfully,

Frank Burling.

Dear Major MacKay:-

I have read Departmental letter 151-9-1 dated February 18th 1939 with regard to the conditions existing at the Hazelton Indian Day School.

My report on this school dated October 16th 1938 sets out the conditions in considerable detail. It is not possible for me to visit this school again during the present academic year without great interference in the inspection work of schools not as yet visited. Further as I have little hope that there has been any great improvement at Hazelton, I believe that it is in the interests of the Department that I refrain from visiting that school till such time as I must carry out an inspection in the academic year 1939-40, probably either in October 1939 or April 1940.

May I say that without in any way withdrawing anything I may have reported in a professional way with regard to the school or Mr Burling's work, I particularly wish to cooperate with Mr Hoey and Mr Phelan in the general administration policy. If it is felt by the Department that for various reasons it would be better to give way to the Anglican Bishop and retain Mr Burling as teacher for one more year I am perfectly willing to refrain from making any observation which might embarrass the Department. In all such cases my wish is that the Superintendent of Welfare and Training should know the exact conditions that exist, and in this case I am perfectly certain that the poor conditions at Hazelton are perfectly well understood. The people that object to the removal of Mr Burling are only a very small percentage of the Indians, and outside the Indian Agent's reports and my own there is nothing to show that the Catholic and Salvation Army children outnumber the Anglican in Hazelton.

May I suggest that Mr Burling be informed that if permitted to remain another year at Hazelton he simply must follow the instructions given to him by the Inspector of Indian Schools and improve the standing of the various Grades in his school. I believe that he should be further informed that the Department does not approve of meetings of protest in regard to criticism of policy or officials, and that his further retention will depend entirely on the reports received from the Indian Agent and Inspector of Schools.
Several reasons prompt me to give this advice. In particular it may not be possible to erect a new two-room Indian Day School at Hazelton during the 1939-40 fiscal year. Should such a school be erected it is to be hoped that it will not be placed under Anglican auspices, but I quite realize that the present may not be a very suitable time to make a general decision with regard to the future policy in respect to the possible non employment of Missionaries as teachers in our schools.

In conclusion may I again say that I am only anxious that the real facts should be known in Ottawa. Mr Hoey may rest assured that I have no intention of making any report that might prove embarrassing.

Yours very truly,

Gerald H. Barry,
Inspector of Indian Schools, B.C.
Ottawa, March 25, 1939.

May I state, also, that the Department does not approve of meetings of protest by Indians, at which meetings the policy of the Department and departmental officials is usually criticised and criticised unfairly.
