Dear Major MacKay:

With reference to letter from Bishop Rix dated June 22nd, I am not able to deal with this letter as I do not know just what has happened lately with reference to the northern schools.

I would ask, therefore, before you prepare a reply to the Bishop or a letter to the Department covering the nominations, to refer to Mr. Kinley's file. He was formerly teacher of the Gitlakdamix Indian Day School. I think you will find that the Department decided Mr. Kinley was not to be appointed as a teacher of any Indian Day School. He is not a trained teacher as you know, and was, in my opinion, a complete failure at Gitlakdamix, from which position the Department eventually removed him.

Reverend B. Sherman is now really too old for teaching work. I am not certain of his exact age but believe it to be about sixty-five. It is mentioned in my reports on the Kitkatla school. Should Mr. Sherman desire to go to Metlakatla, he would, I think, be quite a success there, at least for a year or two.

Dear Major MacKay:

I have written to Miss Jenner asking if she will take charge of the Indian School at Hazelton. If I have a favourable answer from her I will at once notify you.

I am sorry that Mrs. Henderson has left Aiyansh. In case no one else turns up for this school we should fall back on Mr. Kinley, who did at least passable work there in the Fall.

I have informed Mr. Shearman of Kitkatla that I would recommend him for Metlakatla. He has decided that he cannot carry on the heavy school at Kitkatla. I understand the Metlakatla school is much lighter. I herewith recommend this change. This leaves Kitkatla, Greenville and Kitwancool definitely vacant. I am writing to a man today who might take Kitkatla. I am not sure if he has teachers' qualifications, but in these days we cannot afford to be too particular.

I regret that the teacher from Metlakatla was removed. She was well liked by the people and the pupils, but the Indian Agent found her lacking in discipline. If you could get in touch with her she might consider working in some other of our schools and from the first insist upon discipline.

I feel that if the Department does not make the Indian teachers prospect more attractive they will not be able to fill the schools.

re- Hazelton Indian Day School

Replying to your letter of June 22, I wish to advise that the attendance at this school has been very irregular mainly due to sickness, there having been epidemics of 'flu, mumps and measles during the year. However, some pupils have attended irregularly due to their families having moved away for indefinite periods on account of employment. For example, several families proceed to the canneries early in May to fish for spring salmon. Employment in war industries etc. has claimed others, whilst some trappers take the family with them.

The school building, owned by the Anglican Church, is just the same as it has been for a long period of years and, no doubt, would have been vacated in favour of a new school but for the war.

Sports days have been held in about every village sometime in May for years, and it is the practice of the teachers to mark the registers and dismiss the children on such occasions. Probably, in this case, no children attended on the afternoon in question. Children from other reserves attend with their parents, taking the whole day off.

I do not think the Rev. Frank Burling enjoys good enough health to carry on as a teacher. He informed me last fall that he only accepted the position to accommodate Bishop Rix.

S. Mallinson,
Indian Agent.

I wish to acknowledge your letter of December 12th, 1944, enclosing copies of letters from the Right Reverend G.A. Rix and from Mrs. Katherine S.S. Bird, Teacher of the Hazelton Indian Day School.

In talking the matter over with Mrs. Bird during the Christmas holidays it was decided to try out a method to cope with the number of pupils attending this school. For over two months now Mrs. Bird has taught grades 3-7 each morning and grades 1-2 each afternoon. This has been quite successful and each grade has really accomplished quite as much as previously when all classes were in school the entire day. Mrs. Bird informs me she has an attendance of over 20 both in the forenoon and afternoon.

The pupils of this school only stay away on account of sickness or on account of some other valid excuse. Mrs. Bird's personality has an attraction for the scholars and they attend quite regularly.

According to my records there are 35 boys and 41 girls of school age belonging to this reserve but, so many families are away I have no knowledge as to the number of those not residing here. However, I think every child on the reserve at the present time is attending school.

The month of May usually shows a decrease in attendance which becomes very marked in June. September also has a below average attendance. A large number of families are at the canneries during these three months which lowers the attendance considerably. The average attendance for 1944 is as follows:

February - 30.1  March - 32.9  April - 39.5

15. If Form T.D.1 (Revised January 1946) Not Filed By Employee. Any employee who fails to file a completed Form T.D.1 (Revised January 1946) must be regarded for tax deduction purposes as a single person without dependents.

16. Employer to Disallow Claims for Excessive Number of Dependents. To be entitled to the full tax credits for a dependent other than the taxpayer's own child(ren) or grandchild(ren) (or children as defined in Item 8 (1) above), a taxpayer must declare at least $400 per annum to the support of such dependent. Many persons are unaware of this limitation. For tax deduction purposes, employers will be instructed to reduce the salary or wage of any employee claiming more than two such dependents in Item 5 as if the employee had only two dependents in addition to his own child(ren) or grandchild(ren) (or children as defined in Item 8 (1) above). The employer will notify the employee that he must submit proof of any claim for more dependents to the District Inspector of Income Tax. If the employee proves to the satisfaction of the Inspector that he has entitled to further allowances, the employer will be advised accordingly.

17. Employer to Scrutinize Claims by Single Persons for Married Status. The definition of a "Self-contained Domestic Establishment" contained in Item 9 indicates clearly that a taxpayer is not entitled to claim Married Status as a reason of supporting a dependent therein unless the dependent actually resides with the taxpayer. Therefore, employers are instructed to examine addresses shown under Items 4 (F) with the taxpayer's own address in Item 2 (which should show where he is actually living at the time of making the declaration) and in every case where the addresses are not the same, the employer shall make deductions as if the taxpayer were a single person, with or without dependents as the case may be.

18. Employer's Responsibility Regarding Form T.D.1. The employer will have regard to the instructions contained in Items 10 and 17 above and will otherwise make certain that the form is fully completed. If any employee shows children under 16 years of age as dependents under Items 4 or 5, he must also complete Item 6 or the employer shall not take account of such dependents under 16 years of age for tax deduction purposes. He will also delete as a dependent under Item 5 the name of any person whom the employee has already listed in Item 4 unless the claim for married status came within the previous (C) period. If the employer chooses to believe that any of the information on this form is incorrect or false, he will not act upon the declaration until the employee has made the appropriate confirmation or correction. In case of doubt, the matter should be referred to the District Inspector of Income Tax.

19. Action upon Receipt of Amended Form T.D.1 during Currency of Year. Employees are required to file an amended Form T.D.1 if any change occurs in status or dependents. The employer must give immediate effect to a change from "Single" status to "Married" status due to an increase in the number of dependents and to any substantial change (i.e. in excess of $1.00 per month) in Family Allowance cheques. A change from "Married" status to "Single" status (e.g. where the employee becomes a widower) should not be made effective until the first pay period in the next calendar year because the employee will still be classified as single ("Married") status for the whole of the calendar year in which the change took place. Similarly, a decrease in the number of dependents should not generally require a change in the deduction until the following calendar year, with one important exception due to the provision that a taxpayer may not claim as a dependent any person who has an income in excess of $400 during the calendar year. If, for example, a son who was previously supported by the employee and was claimed as a dependent on Form T.D.1 takes up employment from which he will earn over $400 during the calendar year, immediate effect should be given to the amended Form T.D.1 as otherwise the employee will be left with a substantial balance of tax to pay with his return on Form T.1 Special or T.1 General.

With reference to your letter of the 15th instant, the Department approves the following expenditures at the Hazelton Indian Day School:

1. $450.00 for material and labour to prepare Church Army Hall for classroom purposes.

2. $400.00 for desks, blackboards, and other furnishings.

Bernard F. Neary,

Indian Affairs Branch, Dept. of Mines & Resources, Ottawa.

I am enclosing Mr. Indian Agent Boys' letter of October 28th and enclosure referred to therein, together with lists of the school age and pre-school age children on the Hazelton Indian Reserve. It will be noted from the information provided that it is imperative that we open a second classroom on this reserve to accommodate over 30 children in grades 2 to 5 inclusive, presently enrolled at the school, leaving the 34 children in grade 1 in the present classroom.

The Church Army Hall, property of the band, is available for use as a second classroom at a rental of $60.00 per annum and an expenditure of approximately $450.00 for material and labour will be necessary to make it suitable for our purpose. Desks and other furnishings, including blackboards will cost approximately $400.00, and it would be appreciated if these expenditures could be approved, if funds are available for this purpose.

You will note that Mr. Boys refers to Adjutant Rendall, the Salvation Army Officer at Hazelton, who has agreed to accept the position as teacher of the second classroom. I have been in communication with Bishop Gibson regarding the appointment of a Salvation Army official as teacher on a reserve which was formerly considered as an Anglican Mission Field, his letter of November 7th in this connection being enclosed. Adjutant Rendall's services will be available if and when required and a recommendation will be made with regard to his appointment and salary when departmental approval has been obtained for opening the second classroom and carrying out the necessary improvements and purchases.

D. M. MacKay,
Indian Commissioner for B.C.

Education

The need here, when material and funds are available, is a three, possibly four roomed school at Hazelton, with quarters, on a strictly undenominational basis and taking in Hagwilget the staff to include one Catholic teacher in order to avoid religious repercussions as sectarian division of feeling seems to run higher here among the three main divisions of the churches than elsewhere in the Province. BABINE INDIAN AGENCY

Education We are most fortunate in having Mrs. Massey at Hazelton where she has been good naturedly handling much too large a class without complaint, but the new class room is just about ready to open and should be in operation by the 13th of January with some improvisation of desks and seats pending arrival of new ones, although the appointment of a teacher has not yet been made, due to the local applicant's tardiness in the matter. Major D.M. MacKay, Indian Commissioner for B.C. Vancouver, B.C.

I enclose herewith application of Mr. Clarence Rendell for position as teacher for the senior class-room now being prepared for Hazelton Indian Day School. It will be noted that he has taught for twelve years in Newfoundland schools and holds what he considers to be the equivalent of a B.C. 1st class teacher's certificate. He is a Salvation Army Officer.

Anglicans and Salvationists are in about equal numbers on Hazelton Indian Reserve, although Mr. Boys' survey gave the Anglicans a small majority but this was due to rating the Ben McKenzie family as Catholics instead of Salvation Army, in error according to my information.

Mrs Jane Massey, who will take the Primary grade, is an Anglican and there would appear to be no valid objection to the appointment of a Protestant of another church, particularly as the Anglican Church was asked by Mr. Boys if they could supply a teacher and they admitted that they were unable. Mr. Rendell is aware, of course, that the school is pretty much on an undenominational basis and there is no room for the intrusion of any institutional bias. It is proposed that he take the senior class in the class-room now being prepared.

As he has his own quarters I would recommend that he be paid on the same basis as Mrs Massey, that is, $131.00 per month and would recommend approval of his application.

(James Coleman)
Inspector of Indian Agencies.
